Celestial Dust

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
As if the stars had lost their way.
Each flake, a cosmic pilgrim, hovered
Before joining earth's display.

The pines stood dark against the whiteness,
Sentinels of the changing scene,
As daylight dimmed to spectral brightness
And shadows stretched between.

I watched from windows steamed with breathing,
My fingers tracing phantom trails,
As nature's quiet unceasing weaving
Transformed the hills and vales.

The silence grew with each new layer,
A hush that spoke of time suspended,
As if the world had paused in prayer
Before the old year ended.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Until we could no longer tell
Where earth ended, where sky took over,
Entranced within this frozen spell.

White Amnesia

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
A soft erasure of what came before.
Memories buried, like seeds under clover,
Waiting for warmth to restore.

The fences disappeared by morning,
Property lines dissolved away.
No warnings heeded, no forewarning,
Just white democracy held sway.

I ventured out when it had settled,
My boots the first to break the crust,
And felt somehow strangely unsettled
By this clean slate of frozen dust.

For in this canvas, unmarked, waiting,
Lay possibilities untold,
A chance to set aside our hating,
To write new stories, brave and bold.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
And in that brief unwritten hour,
I glimpsed what we might yet discover
If we embraced renewal's power.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

responses.text:
White Whispers

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Soft flakes drifting like forgotten promises.
Each crystalline star a universe unto itself,
Falling in silent communion with the earth.

The streets transformed to alabaster paths,
Footprints becoming temporary history,
As if the universe decided memories
Were too heavy for this delicate day.

Children's laughter rings through muffled air,
Their mittened hands sculpting joy from cold.
While I stand watching at frosted glass,
Feeling the world's heartbeat slow beneath white.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Burying yesterday's sorrows and tomorrow's fears,
Teaching us the gentle art of beginning again,
In the blank page of winter's quiet redemption.

Endless White

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Blankets of silence cascading from gray skies.
Time suspended in crystalline moments,
As earth donned its winter disguise.

The pines bow reverently under white weight,
Streams pause mid-journey, frozen in thought.
Birds huddle close, their songs held in waiting,
As nature's cold canvas is carefully wrought.

I watch from my window, breath clouding glass,
As boundaries blur between land and air.
The familiar grows strange in this pale transformation,
Ordinary magic beyond compare.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Each flake a letter in winter's patient verse.
Teaching us how beauty arrives in stillness,
And how endings and beginnings converse.

The Great Whitening

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
A revolution of white against the dark.
Each house and tree and sleeping flower
Became anonymous under winter's mark.

The city's jagged edges softened now,
Its noise absorbed by cotton-weighted air.
Even the clocks seemed hesitant to move,
As if time itself needed time to spare.

I walked through streets transformed to wonderlands,
My footsteps carving temporary art.
The only color: a cardinal's defiant red,
A small flame burning in winter's heart.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Erasing boundaries between yours and mine.
Perhaps this is what peace might look like—
A shared blanket crossing every border line.

Winter's Democracy

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Democratic flakes on mansion and on shack.
No preference for mountain or for valley,
No discrimination of forward or of back.

The rich man's garden and the pauper's patch
Receive the same immaculate white dress.
The busy highway and forgotten lane
Both disappear in equal loveliness.

How strange that cold can bring such warmth of thought,
That absence of color reveals such truth.
In whiteness, we find our common ground,
A temporary truce from age and youth.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Teaching us what we struggle to believe:
That we are equal under heaven's eyes,
United in what we receive and what we leave.

The Great Silence

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
As if the sky had secrets to conceal.
Each flake a whispered message falling,
Too delicate for humans to reveal.

The chaos of our lives now blanketed,
Our footprints disappearing as we walk.
The universe imposing quietude,
Where once was endless, meaningless talk.

I stand amid this gentle revolution,
Watching as the world accepts its fate.
The trees, once proud, now bow in reverence,
As nature demonstrates what makes us great.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Teaching patience to our restless souls.
In whiteness finding unexpected peace,
In silence finding what makes us whole.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

responses.text:
Endless Blanket

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Soft crystals falling from gray skies above.
Each flake a tiny frozen lover,
Descending with celestial love.

The pines stood draped in winter's gown,
Their branches heavy with pristine white.
As silence settled on the town,
And darkness yielded to the light.

The world transformed before my eyes,
A canvas painted pure and clean.
Where troubles fade and sorrow dies,
In this immaculate winter scene.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Until the earth and sky were one.
And I, a grateful, humble rover,
Stood witness to what time had done.

Winter's Embrace

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
A blanket white as dove's soft wing.
Earth slumbered deep beneath this cover,
As winter wrote what spring would bring.

The cities hushed their constant roar,
As flakes descended without sound.
And children pressed against the door,
Eager for play on hallowed ground.

It snowed until the sharp edges blurred,
Of life's harsh corners, once defined.
Until the heart, so deeply stirred,
Found peace it thought was left behind.

For in this white expanse of time,
When all the world lies still and bare,
There dwells a sanctity sublime,
A perfect moment, crystal-rare.

The Great Equalizer

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Erasing boundaries we had made.
No rich, no poor, no king, no pauper,
Just white perfection, undismayed.

The busy streets fell into silence,
The factories ceased their belching smoke.
Nature imposed her soft compliance,
As if the earth itself awoke.

We stood as equals in the falling,
Of heaven's tears turned crystal cold.
A gentle reminder, most appalling,
That we are small and not so bold.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Until our differences were gone.
And we became, both friend and stranger,
Just silhouettes against the dawn.

Frozen Memories

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Like scattered pages from time's book.
Each flake a memory to discover,
If only we would stop to look.

My childhood home beneath the drifting,
My mother's smile now lost to years.
The weight of snow somehow uplifting
The burden of unspoken fears.

The world outside my window changing,
Yet somehow staying just the same.
As constellations, rearranging,
Still burn with their eternal flame.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Until the past and present met.
And I, both child and aged rover,
Found peace in what we can't forget.

Universal Quiet

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
From mountain peak to ocean shore.
Each continent a pristine cover,
Of white that whispered, "Nothing more."

The chaos of our human making,
Subdued beneath this gentle weight.
As if the universe was taking
A breath before it sealed our fate.

No border lines could now be sighted,
No flags to mark what we call ours.
Just one vast canvas, all united,
Beneath the cold, indifferent stars.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
A message sent from sky to earth.
That we are merely passing over,
This planet that gave us our birth.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

responses.text:
# Endless Winter

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Silent flakes descending from gray skies above.
Each crystal a whisper of forgotten time,
Blanketing memories in pure white love.

Cities disappeared beneath the drifting down,
Mountains and valleys merged as one.
The hard edges of humanity softened,
As Earth donned her glistening winter gown.

No footprints marked the pristine fields,
No voices carried through the muffled air.
Just the gentle weight of accumulation,
And the hush of a world beyond compare.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Time suspended in crystalline grace.
And we, mere witnesses to nature's power,
Stood humbled in winter's cold embrace.

# The Great Whitening

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
A billion crystals dancing down,
Burying summer's distant memory
Beneath winter's frozen crown.

The pines bent low with heavy burden,
Streets vanished without a trace.
Even the sun seemed to surrender
To the white void's cold embrace.

Children's laughter punctured silence
As they carved angels in the deep.
While old ones watched through frosted windows,
Reminiscing times they keep.

It snowed until the world grew quiet,
Until differences disappeared.
Rich and poor and all between them
By the same white blanket smeared.

Perhaps in this great equalizing,
In nature's democratic art,
We glimpse what might be possible
If peace could fill each human heart.

# White Oblivion

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Until the earth was but a ghost.
The mountains, valleys, rivers, forests—
All surrendered to winter's host.

The flakes fell thick as ancient stories,
Building layers of pristine white.
Erasing boundaries between nations,
Transforming darkness into light.

I watched from my window, breath fogging,
As familiar landscapes disappeared.
The neighbor's house, once red and sturdy,
Now just a shadow, vague and smeared.

Perhaps this is how endings happen—
Not with thunder, rage or fight,
But with gentle accumulation
Of moments, soft as snow at night.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
And in that cold, unbroken sweep,
I found strange comfort in the knowledge
That all we build returns to sleep.

# Universal Blanket

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
From Arctic peaks to desert sand.
Anomalous and unrelenting,
A frozen touch on every land.

Palm trees drooped with heavy burdens,
Pyramids wore caps of white.
Venice canals froze still as paintings,
Jungles hushed in snowbound night.

Scientists stood baffled, speechless,
As instruments displayed the strange.
This global winter, unexpected,
Hinted at a climate changed.

Yet children everywhere rejoiced,
Building snowmen where none had stood.
Igloo villages in Havana,
Snowball fights in Hollywood.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Nature's great equalizing act.
Reminding us through transformation
Of our shared and fragile pact.

# The Great Forgetting

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
A quiet erasure of what came before.
Footprints vanished beneath fresh powder,
As time itself paused at winter's door.

The bustling cities grew still and silent,
Their jagged skylines smoothed by white.
The farmlands and the wild meadows
Indistinguishable in fading light.

I wondered as I watched it falling,
If memories too could disappear—
Covered gently, layer by layer,
Until the pain we carried cleared.

Perhaps that's why we love the snowfall,
The temporary amnesia it brings.
The world reborn in pristine whiteness,
Absolved of all its broken things.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
And in that soft, forgiving deep,
I found myself at last unburdened,
Ready for the thaw, the green, the leap.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
Vanishing Waters

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
Mirrors of a sky growing distant and pale.
Where once rivers rushed with unbridled might,
Now only whispers of moisture catch the light.

The earth cracks in thirst around these shrinking isles,
Memories of abundance stretch for miles.
Fish circle tighter in their narrowing homes,
As the sun beats down on bleaching stones.

I cup my hands around these fragile remnants,
Knowing tomorrow may claim what heaven sent.
In these shallow depths, I see our reflection—
A world of plenty reduced to dejection.

Who will remember when waters flowed free?
When life burst forth in wild symphony?
Just a few dwindling pools remain,
Bearing witness to our collective pain.

Desert Memory

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where once an ocean kissed the shore.
Silver mirrors catching clouds and light,
Shrinking daily, asking nothing more
Than to exist until tomorrow's dawn.

Turtles gather at these final wells,
Ancient pilgrims to a sacred space.
Their shells tell stories of abundant times
When water wasn't such a fleeting grace.

I kneel beside these precious liquid gems,
Watching ripples spread from fingertips.
The desert waits with patient, hungry breath
To claim what moisture from the landscape slips.

In these pools, I see eternity—
The cycle of abundance and of lack.
The way all things must someday fade away,
And if we're blessed, perhaps then circle back.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
But in their depths, whole worlds contain.

Ephemeral

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
Cupped in stone palms of ancient earth.
The sky reflects in fractured blue,
A memory of former worth.

I trace the edges where water once rose,
Rings of sediment marking time.
How quickly abundance becomes scarcity—
Nature's warning in muddy grime.

Dragonflies hover, desperate scouts
Searching for what they've always known.
Fish crowd tighter in shrinking space,
Survival instinct fully grown.

I too am searching for something lost,
Some reservoir of former grace.
The moisture of hope evaporating
From my heart's drought-stricken place.

Perhaps we're all just waiting for rain,
For floods to fill our empty parts.
Just a few dwindling pools remain—
In landscapes, lifetimes, and in hearts.

Last Waters

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
Like memories refusing to fade.
Shimmering under the relentless sun,
Last witnesses to promises made.

The creatures gather in silent prayer,
At these shrines of diminishing blue.
Hooves and paws print the muddy shores,
As life converges, desperate and true.

I've watched these waters recede for years,
Shrinking like opportunities missed.
The map of abundance redrawn each day,
By heat and time and negligent fist.

We speak of conservation in hushed tones,
As if volume could hasten the rain.
But nature listens not to our words,
Only actions could restore her domain.

So I guard these pools with vigilant heart,
Knowing each drop holds universes within.
Just a few dwindling pools remain—
Perhaps enough for us to begin again.

Remnants

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where once a mighty river flowed.
Time-carved basins in ancient stone,
Keepers of what heaven bestowed.

I stand at the edge of what's left behind,
Watching tadpoles race against fate.
Their urgent circles in murky depths
Ask questions I cannot translate.

How many sunrises will paint these pools
Before dust reclaims liquid light?
How many creatures will drink their fill
Before water surrenders to night?

I've seen this pattern in human hearts—
The slow recession of what sustained,
Until passion, once flooding our veins,
Becomes memory, carefully contained.

Perhaps in scarcity lies the truth:
What's precious is what's nearly gone.
Just a few dwindling pools remain—
Enough to reflect what comes dawn.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
Dwindling Pools

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
Mirrors of a sky growing dim,
Where once rivers flowed without restraint,
Now only memories swim.

The earth cracks in thirsty lines,
Reaching like fingers toward the last wet kiss,
Time measured in evaporation signs,
A countdown to waterless abyss.

I cup my hands around these final drops,
As if prayer might multiply their sum,
While overhead the merciless sun stops
For nothing, and the clouds refuse to come.

In these shallow bowls of fading blue,
Tiny universes gasp their last breath,
What was abundance has reduced to few,
Silent witnesses to a slow, parched death.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
And in their depths, I see our fate reflected clear—
How quickly plenty turns to desperate strain,
How precious becomes what we once held dear.

REMNANTS

Just a few dwindling pools remain
where once an ocean sang its vast refrain.
Silver circles shrinking day by day,
cupped in stone hands that cannot make them stay.

I kneel beside these liquid memories,
watch minnows dart in frantic little vees,
their world contracting with each passing hour,
their universe reduced to dwindling power.

The mud around the edges crusts and cracks,
draws maps of loss in brown and brittle tracks.
What life clings here grows desperate in its hold,
as water thins and secrets all unfold.

I think of all the things we've watched recede—
love's fullness, youth's bright promise, faith's firm creed.
How everything that seemed so deep and wide
eventually finds its ebbing tide.

Just a few dwindling pools remain.
I cup one in my palms like captured rain,
and in its trembling surface, briefly see
all that was, all that will cease to be.

VANISHING POINT

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where once a rushing river carved its way.
Sun-dappled mirrors shrinking in the plain,
Shrines to abundance from a wetter day.

The parched earth cracks in geometric grief
Around these last wet offerings of sky.
I watch them vanish, knowing their relief
Is temporary as clouds passing by.

Small creatures gather at these final brinks—
A desperate congregation come to pray
At water temples where they sip and drink
As if tomorrow might resemble yesterday.

I too have felt my own reserves run low,
The well of hope diminished to a trace.
Those spaces where my dreams once used to flow
Now shallow basins in a desert place.

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Of all I thought would never drain away.
I cup my hands to catch what drops sustain
And wonder what will quench me when they fade.

THE LAST WATERS

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
Like memories that refuse to fade completely.
They shimmer under the indifferent sun,
Small galaxies of water, reluctant to surrender.

I remember when the lake stretched beyond sight,
When children's laughter echoed across its surface,
When boats carved gentle wakes through summer evenings,
Before the earth grew thirsty beyond quenching.

Now fish circle in tightening orbits,
Their silver bodies flashing desperate signals.
Herons stand sentinel at shrinking shores,
Philosophers contemplating impermanence.

The mud around these final pools
Cracks into patterns like ancient text—
Hieroglyphics spelling drought and warning,
Messages we've chosen not to translate.

Just a few dwindling pools remain.
I kneel beside one, see my reflection fractured.
What will we tell the children of tomorrow
When they ask where all the waters went?

In my cupped hands, I hold what little stays,
Watching it seep through fingers, returning
To the parched earth that waits below,
Patient as only the dying can be.

DIMINISHING WATERS

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where once a mighty current swept the land.
Nature's mirrors, growing small and plain,
Cupped in hollows of unforgiving sand.

I watch their edges shrink with every hour,
Receding like the hairline of the old.
The sun, relentless in its burning power,
Claims back the moisture that the earth can't hold.

Small creatures gather at these final banks—
A dragonfly, a sparrow, thirsty deer—
All sharing water with reluctant thanks,
As if they sense the ending drawing near.

I think of how we take abundance blindly,
Assume that plenty never finds its end,
Until we face the truth that speaks unkindly:
All reservoirs eventually must spend.

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Of all we thought would last beyond our days.
I dip my fingers in the cool refrain
And feel time passing through this liquid phase.

Perhaps in dwindling we find what matters—
The precious nature of each drop that falls.
In scarcity, illusion finally shatters;
In emptiness, the fullest wisdom calls.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
LAST WATERS

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
Cradled in earth's parched, cracking palm.
Memories of rivers, wild and untamed,
Now whispers beneath a merciless sun.

Life gathers at these shrinking shores—
Wings and paws and desperate prayers.
Each ripple precious, each droplet more
Valuable than all our human wares.

I watch reflections fracture and mend
In these last mirrors of a vanishing world.
How strange that we only comprehend
The worth of waters as they unfurl

Into absence. I kneel at the edge,
Cupping hope in my hands like rain,
Offering back what we failed to pledge
When abundance made us vain.

REMNANTS

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where once an ocean kissed the shore.
Silver mirrors catching clouds and pain,
Fragments of what flowed before.

I walk among these memory wells,
Footprints filling with brackish tears.
Each puddle holds a story, tells
Of abundance drowned by passing years.

The fish that darted, scaled with light,
The children's laughter, summer-sweet,
All ghosts now in the fading sight
Of water surrendering to defeat.

I cup my hands around these shrinking dreams,
Watching time erode what once seemed vast.
How strange that loss so clearly gleams,
Reflecting futures in our drying past.

Just a few dwindling pools remain—
Enough to mourn, perhaps enough to save.

DROUGHT SONGS

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where children once sailed paper boats.
The creek bed cracks like ancient runes,
Each fissure spelling thirst.

The herons have abandoned us.
Their absence louder than any cry
As shadows stretch across the dust
Where tadpoles used to dance.

I remember when the water sang,
When it carried secrets from mountain to sea.
Now silence settles like fine silt
Over memories too fluid to hold.

My grandfather said the rains would come.
He read promises in cloud formations,
In the way certain beetles burrowed deep.
His wisdom dried up with the last spring.

We wait beside these shrinking mirrors,
Our reflections growing more desperate each day.
Just a few dwindling pools remain—
Enough to keep hope from evaporating completely.

OASIS

Just a few dwindling pools remain
In this desert of manufactured days.
I guard them like precious stones,
These moments of clarity amid chaos.

Remember when our lives overflowed?
When time was a river, not these scattered
Droplets of presence between deadlines,
Notifications, and digital demands.

I visit these pools at dawn sometimes,
When the world hasn't fully loaded its noise.
I touch the cool surface of silence,
Watch ripples of thought expand outward.

These waters hold reflections
Of who I was before the drought,
Before we began harvesting attention
Like a resource to be drained and sold.

I'm learning to conserve what matters—
To cup these moments carefully in my palms,
To drink deeply while just a few dwindling pools remain,
To become the vessel that might carry them forward.

EVAPORATION

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where once our love rushed wild and deep.
I trace their shrinking edges, mapping
The geography of what we couldn't keep.

Remember how we swam in midnight waters?
How we dove beneath surfaces, fearless and free?
Now I wade through ankle-deep remnants,
Collecting memories before they cease to be.

The sun has had its way with us.
Time, that relentless thief of moisture.
Words unspoken—those subtle evaporations
That no one notices until the shore shifts.

I photograph these final puddles,
Document their shapes like evidence.
As if proving they existed might somehow
Reverse the verdict of their disappearance.

Perhaps all love ends this way—
Not in dramatic floods but slow retreat,
Until just a few dwindling pools remain
As testament to what once seemed complete.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where once a mighty river flowed,
Mirrors reflecting clouded sky,
Shrinking islands in parched earth.

Time's patient fingers slowly press
Upon these fragile liquid eyes,
Each day they grow a little less,
Each dawn reveals another loss.

The creatures gather, desperate now,
At edges cracked and caked with mud.
They do not speak of yesterday
When water stretched beyond their sight.

I too have known such slow retreat,
Such gradual diminishing of hope.
Watching memories evaporate
Like morning dew beneath the sun.

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Of all we were, of all we built.
Soon even these will disappear
Leaving only dust to mark their place.

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where oceans once caressed the shore.
Summer's breath, relentless, cruel,
Has claimed what time could not before.

The fish, once silver-scaled and swift,
Lie still in shallow, warming graves.
Their bodies curl like question marks
Asking why the water saves so few.

I walk between these shrinking worlds,
My footprints filling, briefly, with
The memory of abundance, then
Drying quickly in the thirsty air.

The mud cracks form a broken map
To nowhere anyone would go.
Yet in the deepest pool, I see
A single lotus, still aglow

With possibility. Its roots
Reach down to secret springs below.
Just a few dwindling pools remain,
But in their depths, tomorrow grows.

Just a few dwindling pools remain

Beneath the desert's burning eye
The earth lies cracked and broken now
Where verdant valleys used to lie.

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Like memories that refuse to fade
The last teardrops of dying land
That time and drought cannot persuade.

The turtles gather, ancient, wise
Their shells like weathered monuments
To wetter days and cooler skies
Before the balance grew so tense.

A heron stands on slender legs
Its patience outlasts even stone
It knows that life persists and begs
For mercy from the vast unknown.

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Yet in their depths, I see it clear:
The resilience of life contained
In every drop we hold so dear.

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Of childhood's vast imagined seas,
Where once I sailed tall pirate ships
And dove for treasure on my knees.

The sandbox ocean shrinks with age,
Its shores recede with passing years.
The castles built with careful hands
Have crumbled under adult fears.

I visit still these shallow depths,
These puddles of remembered joy,
And see reflected in their face
The fading outline of a boy.

The universe that once expanded
Within my bedroom's four plain walls
Now narrows to appointments kept,
To bills, deadlines, and duty calls.

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where wonder hasn't yet run dry.
I cup them gently in my hands
And drink before they too can die.

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where once abundance flowed like grace,
Silver mirrors catching clouds,
The sky's reflection in earth's face.

I stand beside their shrinking shores,
Watching ripples fade to still.
The water's edge retreats each day,
Surrendering to summer's will.

The deer come hesitant at dusk,
Their thin legs trembling as they drink.
They sense as I do what's at stake—
How close we stand to some brink.

In these last waters, life condenses,
Intensifies its fragile hold.
Tadpoles race against the sun,
Their transformation swift and bold.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
Yet in their depths I clearly see
How precious grows what's growing scarce,
How drought reveals what plenty conceals.
How thirst becomes our teacher now.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
Dwindling Pools

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
Shrinking mirrors of cloudless sky,

Now just whispers of what used to be.

The earth cracks in thirsty patterns,
Mouth open wide in silent plea,
As memory of abundance fades
With each passing, merciless day.

Fish bones scattered like ancient runes,

I cup my hands around what's left,

Just a few dwindling pools remain,

REMNANTS

Just a few dwindling pools remain
where oceans of us once gathered.
The tide of years has pulled away,
leaving only scattered memories

like shells half-buried in wet sand.
I walk among these shallow depths,
my reflection fractured, incomplete,
as I search for what we were before.

The sun beats down without mercy,
evaporating what little is left.
I cup my hands to save some part
of our history before it disappears.

But water has its own intentions,
slipping through fingers like promises
we made when the world was full
and we believed in endless abundance.

Just a few dwindling pools remain.
I kneel beside them in reverence,
watching ripples expand from my tears
as they fall into what remains of us.

DROUGHT MEMORIES

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where children once splashed with abandon,
Their laughter evaporated like the water itself,
Leaving only mud-cracked memories.

I remember when the lake stretched beyond sight,
When fishermen cast their hopes with each line,
When boats carved gentle wakes across the surface
That now bears only the footprints of desperate creatures.

The old dock stands useless, reaching toward
Nothing but dust and scattered stones,
Its weathered planks a calendar of abundance,
Marking water levels that recede in my mind.

The earth remembers what we try to forget—
How we took without thinking, drained without pause.
Now we pray to clouds that pass indifferently overhead,
Offering nothing but shadows across the parched land.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
Holding our reflection like a final judgment,
Shimmering briefly before they too will vanish,
Leaving us alone with our unquenchable thirst.

EPHEMERAL WATERS

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
Cupped in stone hands of ancient earth,
Like tears collected after rainfall,
Temporary as morning dew.

Time moves across their surfaces,
Rippling with insect whispers,
Reflecting fragments of passing clouds,
Countdown mirrors growing smaller.

I've watched them shrink through seasons,
These last survivors of the flood,
Holding life in their shallow depths—
Tiny universes soon to vanish.

Tadpoles race against evaporation,
Their metamorphosis a desperate sprint,
As water lilies fold their final prayers
Into buds that may never open.

The desert waits with patient hunger,
Its thirst older than memory,
Knowing all waters eventually return
To sky or sand or distant sea.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
And in their fading reflections,
I see the temporary nature
Of everything I've ever loved.

LAST WATERS

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where once a mighty river flowed.
I stand at the edge of emptiness,
Watching dragonflies hover like memories
Over what little water still catches light.

The mud around these shrinking mirrors
Is etched with stories of desperate thirst—
Deer hooves, raccoon paws, the slithering trace
Of creatures drawn to final moisture
Before the coming of absolute dust.

I remember swimming here as a child,
The current strong enough to carry dreams,
Water so abundant we never thought
To measure or preserve its flowing grace.
How foolish our assumption of forever.

Now I photograph these last reflections,
Documenting disappearance, collecting
The evidence of change no one believed
Would happen in our lifetime. Tomorrow
These pools may be nothing but memory.

Just a few dwindling pools remain.
I cup my hands and lift the water,
Let it fall through my fingers like time,
Like warning, like prayer, like regret
For all we failed to protect when we could.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
Just a few dwindling pools remain,
Mirrors of sky now shrinking fast,
Where once a river proudly flowed,
Only memories of abundance last.

The parched earth cracks in desperate thirst,
As summer's heat beats merciless down.
The creatures gather, tense and wary,
At edges of these liquid crowns.

Time measured now in droplets lost,
To thirsty air and burning light.
Each ripple precious, each reflection
A fading jewel against the blight.

I trace the outline where water reached,
Fingers touching ghosts of dampness gone.
The land remembers what we forget—
This cycle's played since time's first dawn.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
Yet in their depths, life clings with hope.
Waiting for clouds to gather again,
And teach the desert how to cope.

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where once an ocean kissed the shore.
Silent witnesses to what we've done,
They hold our reflections, nothing more.

The fish that danced in silver schools
Have vanished like a morning dream.
Mud-cracked memories of flowing wealth,
A barren promise, a dried-up stream.

I kneel beside these shrinking mirrors,
Cupping remnants in weathered hands.
The water slips between my fingers—
Time passing like these grains of sand.

The earth remembers ancient rhythms
Of flood and drought through countless years.
Perhaps these pools are not an ending
But whispered hope that rain appears.

In depths that shrink with every hour,
Life stubbornly refuses death.
Tiny creatures in murky waters
Await renewal's gentle breath.

DWINDLING WATERS

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
Like memories fading at day's end,
Shimmering under the relentless sun,
Their boundaries slowly rescind.

I remember when waters flowed freely here,
Carving paths through welcoming stone,
Now the riverbed lies exposed and bare,
Its secrets and treasures shown.

Tiny creatures cluster in desperate throngs,
Clinging to what moisture survives,
In these last sanctuaries of liquid hope,
Fragile threads of countless lives.

The sky above, vast and cloudless blue,
Offers no promise of sweet relief,
Only the birds circle, patient witnesses
To this slow unfolding grief.

Yet beneath the mud, seeds lie waiting,
Dormant but filled with potential power,
For when the rains eventually return,
This desert will erupt in flower.

EPHEMERAL WATERS

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where once abundance flowed without end.
Silver mirrors shrinking day by day,
Their boundaries continue to bend.

The desert reclaims what was briefly lent,
A temporary reprieve from thirst and heat.
The sand advances with patient hunger,
As water retreats in slow defeat.

Small tracks of creatures circle inward,
Converging on these last liquid gems.
A heron stands sentinel, watching closely,
As life clings to vanishing stems.

I've seen this cycle turn before—
The fullness, then the slow decline.
Nature's rhythm of give and take,
A dance of water and sunshine.

In these shallow remnants I see myself,
Holding tight to what cannot stay.
Learning the wisdom of letting go,
As all things must change and fade away.

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where rivers once rushed wild and free.
Nature's tears collected in hollows,
Last witnesses to what used to be.

The mud around them cracks and splinters,
A mosaic of earth's desperate thirst.
Turtles crowd in shrinking havens,
Uncertain which fate is worse.

I trace my fingers through tepid water,
Stirring memories of abundant flow.
The land has stories it longs to whisper
Of cycles only elders know.

Dragonflies hover like ancient spirits,
Guardians of moisture's final stand.
Their iridescent wings catch sunlight—
Beauty persisting across dry land.

Perhaps in these remaining puddles
Lies wisdom deeper than their depth:
That even in life's greatest droughts,
Some sanctuary always will be left.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

responses.text:
When I am happy,
The world shimmers like dew on morning grass,
Each breath becomes a gift unwrapped slowly,
And time—that hurried merchant—pauses
To admire the light in my eyes.

When I am happy,
My hands become birds, my thoughts butterflies,
The weight of yesterday dissolves
Into the promise of tomorrow's sunrise.
Even shadows dance with newfound grace.

When I am happy,
Strangers seem like friends I haven't met,
Music lives between my heartbeats,
And simple moments transform
Into treasures I collect beneath my skin.

When I am happy,
I am both smaller and larger than myself—
A paradox of humble gratitude
And boundless possibility,
A human being, simply, completely alive.

When I am happy,
The universe unfolds within me
Like origami stars unfolding
Back into pristine sheets of possibility.

When I am happy,
My bones remember being coral reefs,
My blood recalls its salt-life beginnings,
My eyes reflect the ancient light
Of stars that died to birth me.

When I am happy,
I forgive the rain for falling sideways,
The clock for its persistent ticking,
The mirror for its honest reflections.
I forgive myself for being human.

When I am happy,
The mathematics of existence simplify—
Subtraction becomes addition,
Division multiplies connection,
And the equation balances without effort.

When I am happy,
I become a lighthouse for others lost at sea,
Not because I know the way,
But because I've learned to shine
Even when the fog refuses to lift.

When I am happy,
The clouds part like theater curtains
Revealing the sky's endless blue stage
Where birds perform their wingbeat symphony
Just for me, it seems.

When I am happy,
My coffee tastes of childhood summers,
Of blackberry-stained fingers and
Lemonade secrets shared under oak trees.
Even bitter things turn sweet.

When I am happy,
Street lamps flicker like fireflies,
Concrete sidewalks become forest paths,
And the city's roar transforms
Into the ocean's patient breathing.

When I am happy,
I carry galaxies in my pocket,
Whisper to dandelions like old friends,
And catch falling leaves before they touch ground—
Small miracles become possible.

When I am happy,
I am both ancient and newborn,
A contradiction of wisdom and wonder,
Remembering and discovering
The extraordinary gift of being here at all.

When I am happy,
I become a vessel for light—
The kind that filters through leaves
Creating patterns too beautiful
For any language to describe.

When I am happy,
Time loses its linear discipline;
Moments expand like universes,
Seconds stretch into eternities
Where I can dwell in perfect peace.

When I am happy,
My body remembers its music—
The symphony of heartbeat and breath,
The rhythm of footsteps on earth,
The melody of blood rushing through veins.

When I am happy,
I recognize myself in strangers' eyes,
In the determined sprout breaking through concrete,
In the resilience of stars
That traveled millions of years to reach us.

When I am happy,
I understand that joy is not the absence of pain
But the presence of something greater—
A courage to remain open
To the wild, beautiful uncertainty of being alive.

When I am happy,
The world wears different colors—
Not brighter, necessarily,
But truer, as if happiness
Wipes clean the lens through which I see.

When I am happy,
My hands find purpose in simple tasks:
Folding laundry becomes meditation,
Chopping vegetables transforms into prayer,
Washing dishes becomes an act of gratitude.

When I am happy,
Memories lose their sting;
Regrets soften their sharp edges
And nostalgia wraps around me
Like an old sweater, comfortable in its imperfection.

When I am happy,
I notice how trees converse with wind,
How strangers carry invisible stories,
How silence holds as much meaning
As the most carefully chosen words.

When I am happy,
I am neither running toward nor away—
Just present in this temporary miracle,
This brief intersection of consciousness and time,
This quiet revolution called being fully alive.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

responses.text:

I stretch my arms to embrace

When I am happy,
I am both smaller and larger than myself,

When I am happy,

The earth beneath my feet
Becomes a trampoline,
Bouncing me higher
Than I've ever been.

When I am happy,
My shadow dances
Without my permission,
Taking wild chances.

The moon peeks through clouds
To catch a glimpse of my smile,
And stars rearrange themselves
Just for a while.

When I am happy,
I become a lighthouse
Guiding lost ships home
Through storms of doubt.

And in that moment of joy,
I finally understand
That happiness was never the destination—
It was the journey all along.

When I am happy,
I wear the morning like a silk robe,

The coffee in my cup transforms

When I am happy,
Street noises arrange themselves

Even the grocery store

When I am happy,

When I am happy,
My soul wears no shoes,

The birds seem to know it—

When I am happy,

Tucked away for tomorrow.

The mirror shows a stranger
With eyes I recognize,
A face that finally matches
The person locked inside.

When I am happy,
I become a collector of moments:
A child's first laugh,
The perfect bite of fruit,
A sentence in a book
That feels written just for me.

And I wonder why
I ever called anything else
Living.

When I am happy,

When I am happy,

When I am happy,

When I am happy,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Before me stands I see,'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'One dark, dark night--it was long ago,'

responses.text:
One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
When stars refused to shine their light,
And shadows danced where wind would blow,
Across the moors in silent flight.

I walked alone on cobbled roads,
With nothing but my thoughts for kin,
The weight of memory's heavy loads,
Pressed deep upon my soul within.

The church bells tolled a mournful sound,
As if to mark what time had claimed,
The loves and lives now underground,
The hearts once wild, now tamed.

One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
Yet still it haunts my waking dreams,
The secrets that the darkness knows,
Are never quite as lost as seems.

For in that night I found a truth,
That follows me through all my days,
The shadow of departed youth,
Still lingers in a thousand ways.

One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
When whispers crept through ancient trees,
And moonlight failed to cast its glow
Upon the world's uncertainties.

A child stood at the window pane,
Small fingers pressed against the glass,
Watching droplets from the rain
Trace silver pathways as they passed.

Something stirred beyond the veil
Of ordinary sight and sound—
A memory too fragile, too frail,
That time had buried underground.

What secrets does the darkness keep
When daylight's honest face has turned?
What promises do shadows reap
From truths that should remain unlearned?

One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
Yet still that child within me knows,
Some mysteries are better left to grow
Like wildflowers nobody sows.

One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
The clocks had stopped their faithful ticking,
The world suspended in the throes
Of time's mysterious unraveling.

The village slept beneath a shroud
Of midnight fog and ancient lore,
As I, a traveler, walked unbowed
Through tales untold and paths before.

I heard them then—the voices clear,
Of those who lived in former years,
Their laughter, songs, and even tears,
Echoing across the hemispheres.

The veil between what is and was
Grew thin as gossamer that eve,
No explanation, rhyme or cause,
Just magic I could not perceive.

One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
But in my heart, it lingers still,
A moment when the world let go,
And wonder had its perfect will.

One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
When I discovered time's strange bend,
How memories like rivers flow
To places where all journeys end.

The grandfather clock struck thirteen times,
A door appeared where none had been,
I stepped across forgotten lines
Into a world I'd never seen.

The faces there—half-recognized—
Wore smiles from some ancestral past,
Their eyes with wisdom crystallized,
From lessons learned that always last.

They showed me scrolls of unborn days,
And maps of roads not taken yet,
The intersections and the ways
Where joy and sorrow often met.

One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
I learned that time is but a veil,
That thins when starlight's gentle glow
Reveals the truths behind our tale.

One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
I found myself on childhood's shore,
Where memories like seashells grow
More beautiful than they were before.

The lighthouse beam swept 'cross the bay,
Illuminating for a breath
The ghosts of those who lost their way,
Between the lands of life and death.

My grandmother stood beside me there,
Though she had passed some years before,
The salt breeze moving through her hair,
As if death were an open door.

"Remember," was all she said to me,
Her voice like distant thunder rolled,
"The past and future both will be
Connected by the stories told."

One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
But wisdom gained in darkness stays,
A lantern for the path we go,
Through all our bright and shadowed days.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

responses.text:
Fire:
Dancing embers in the night,
Crackling whispers, burning bright.
Consumer of forests, maker of ash,
Yet giver of warmth when winters crash.

Ancient power in flickering form,
Comfort in cold, danger in storm.
Red and orange tongues that lick the air,
Devouring all with hungry flare.

Primordial force that shaped our path,
Both servant gentle and demon wrath.
In hearths contained, a faithful friend,
Unleashed in fury, brings world's end.

Human history written in flame,
Civilization's rise to claim.
Fire: destroyer, creator, light—
Eternal dance of dark and bright.

Fire:
Speaks in tongues of amber and gold,
Stories older than time itself told.
Beneath stars that witness its ancient birth,
It transforms, consumes, returns to earth.

In its heart, a paradox dwells—
Creation's spark, destruction's bells.
It forged our tools, our dreams, our might,
Yet razed our temples in the night.

Cleansing force with primal voice,
Making ash of regret and choice.
In its dance, we see reflections clear
Of passions burning, love, and fear.

Both hearth-keeper and forest-thief,
It gives no judgment, knows no grief.
Fire: element of transformation's art,
Eternal flame in nature's heart.

Fire:
Unleashed from flint's reluctant kiss,
A spark becomes infinity's abyss.
Hungry child with insatiable need,
On memories and matter it will feed.

In its belly, yesterday dissolves,
As tomorrow from its heat evolves.
It renders judgment without thought,
Leaving lessons painfully taught.

We gather round its primal glow,
Faces illuminated, shadows grow.
In its light, we share our tales,
As beyond the circle, darkness sails.

Both servant and master, friend and foe,
Its true nature we may never know.
Fire: mirror of our own desire,
Reflecting how we fall and aspire.

Fire:
Baptismal touch upon the land,
Writing futures in blackened sand.
Purifier, cleanser, maker new,
Your smoke signals rise into the blue.

In your embrace, metals yield,
Swords are born for battlefield.
In your absence, night prevails,
And winter's bitter cold assails.

You dwell in stars across the void,
In passion's heart, in rage employed.
You cook our meals and forge our chains,
Both blessing given and deadly banes.

We fear your hunger, crave your light,
Since first you chased away the night.
Fire: threshold between worlds unseen,
What was, what is, what might have been.

Fire:
Element of contradictions deep,
Awake while mountains seem to sleep.
Your voice—a crackle, hiss, and roar,
Echoes tales from ancient lore.

Alchemist that turns all things to one,

Within your heart, all secrets melt,
Pain and joy equally felt.

You danced upon primeval shores,
Before we learned to open doors.
In your reflection, we first saw
Our power to create and flaw.

Both sacred vessel, profane force,
Of endings and beginnings source.
Fire: keeper of the hidden name,
Forever changing, still the same.

A gift that cavemen loved and feared.
Stolen from gods with cunning hand,
Transforming beast to thinking man.

In hearth contained, it nurtures life,
Cuts through darkness like a knife.
Gathers tribes in circles warm,
Shelter from the raging storm.

Unleashed, it claims the forest floor,
Hungry flames demanding more.
Purging, cleansing, making way
For new growth on another day.

Metaphor for passion's heat,
Desire's burn that won't retreat.
The spark of thought, creation's light,
Illuminating darkest night.

Element of transformation,
Death and birth in combination.
Ash to phoenix, endless turn—
To live is simply this: to burn.

Fire:
Serpent tongues of orange and gold
Lick the darkness, bright and bold.
Ancient power, primal force,
Running wild without remorse.

In its warmth, we gather close,
Seeing shapes that dance and boast.
Stories whispered through the flames
Echoing ancestral names.

Spark of thought and forge of will,
Promethean gift, burning still.
In every hearth and human heart,
The embers of our very start.

Destructive when it breaks its chains,
Leaving ash where life remains.
Yet from these ashes, green returns—
The cycle that forever burns.

Consumer, creator, light and shade,
From which our greatest tools were made.
In every soul, that same wild spark
That once illumined caves so dark.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

responses.text:
We Have Met Before

Your eyes, familiar as constellations
I've traced a thousand times before,
Bearing echoes of conversations
Held on some distant, forgotten shore.

Perhaps in dreams, or lives long past,
Our souls entwined like ancient vines,
Each meeting brief, yet built to last,
Across the blur of countless times.

I recognize your laugh—a bell
That rang through chambers of my heart
Before this body came to dwell
In time's unfolding work of art.

We have met before, in shadows cast
By firelight on cavern walls,
In royal courts of empires vast,
In humble homes and crowded halls.

So take my hand without a fear,
This reunion was always meant.
Our story started long from here,
And stretches past this brief present.

Déjà Vu

We have met before—
In the curve of a stranger's smile,
In the scent of rain on distant shores,
In the warmth of hands that reached
Across centuries to find mine.

We have met before—
Your voice carries whispers
Of conversations never spoken
In this lifetime, but echoing still
From chambers of ancient memory.

We have met before—
Perhaps as enemies on battlefields,
Or lovers beneath a different moon,
Or passing ships in crowded ports,
Exchanging glances that held universes.

We have met before—
In the spaces between heartbeats,
In the pause before exhaling,
In the moment just before waking,
When reality blurs with dreaming.

We have met before—
And will meet again,
Our souls recognizing what our minds forget,
Tracing patterns across the tapestry of time,
Endlessly finding our way back home.

Familiar Strangers

We have met before,
Though your name escapes these lips,
Your essence stirs memories
Buried beneath consciousness.

Was it in the marketplace
Of a Mediterranean town,
Where spices colored the air
And our hands brushed over ripe fruit?

Or perhaps in a snow-hushed forest,
Where our breath mingled as vapor,
As we tracked deer through ancient pines,
Survival binding our fates?

Maybe we danced in gilded halls,
Candlelight catching in your eyes,
As revolutions brewed outside
And we clutched moments like jewels.

Or were we comrades in trenches,
Mud-soaked and trembling with fear,
Sharing a cigarette and promises
Neither of us could keep?

The how matters less than the truth:
Souls recognize their companions.
Across the veil of forgetting,
We carry maps to find each other.

So here we stand, familiar strangers,
Ready to remember once again.

Echoes of Recognition

We have met before
In the space between heartbeats,
Where time folds like origami
And souls recognize their own reflection.

I knew you in the moment
Before words formed on your tongue—
That slight tilt of your head,
The way shadows gather in your palms.

Perhaps we were warriors
Standing back-to-back in ancient battles,
Or scholars sharing whispered secrets
By candlelight in forgotten libraries.

Maybe we passed as strangers
On rain-slick streets of cities long crumbled,
Our eyes meeting briefly
Before the crowd pulled us apart.

Did we plant gardens together
In some quiet countryside,
Our fingers stained with earth,
Laughter rising like birds at dawn?

The details blur and shift,
But this certainty remains:
We have traveled circles around the sun,
Endlessly finding and losing each other.

Now here, in this present moment,
I recognize you again—
A familiar soul in new clothing,
Returning, as we always do, to begin again.

Cycles of Return

We have met before
In lifetimes worn smooth like river stones,
Your face different yet somehow the same—
A constellation rearranged but recognizable.

I felt it in the electric shock
When our fingers accidentally touched,
In that sudden intake of breath
As if the universe remembered what we forgot.

Were we rivals once, swords crossed
Beneath a blood-orange sunset?
Or healers working side by side
As plagues swept through medieval towns?

Perhaps we shared bread at roadside inns,
Wanderers exchanging tales of distant lands,
Or built stone walls together that still stand
While our names have long since faded.

Maybe we were nothing to each other—
Just passing glances in crowded marketplaces,
Yet something lingered, a thread unbroken
That pulled us back into orbit.

The wheel turns, souls return,
And here we stand again,
Newly introduced yet ancient friends,
Ready to discover what we've always known.

We have met before—
And in this recognition lies our freedom.

And though I cannot place it,
This recognition burns so clear:
We are but souls reuniting
In the endless now and here.

We have met before
In the space between heartbeats
Where souls recognize souls
Before words are ever spoken.

I knew you in the curve of mountains
That matched the arch of your smile,
In the restless ocean waves
That mimicked your unquiet mind.

We have met before
In ancient library corners,
Our fingers brushing over the same
Dog-eared pages of forgotten lore.

Perhaps we were warriors once,
Standing shoulder to shoulder,
Or rivals across battlefield lines,
Or lovers beneath a different sky.

Time is not a river flowing forward
But an ocean where all moments exist at once,
And somewhere in its vast expanse
We have always known each other.

So when you appeared at my door today,
It wasn't hello, but welcome back—
To this familiar stranger
Whom I've always known.

We have met before
In a garden of wild thoughts,
Where the roses bloom in winter
And the snow falls in July.

Your face—a constellation
Mapped across my memory's sky,
Though I cannot trace the moment
When our stars first aligned.

Was it in the hush of twilight
When the world blurs at its edge?
Or amid the morning chaos
Of a life I've tried to hedge?

Your voice carries echoes
Of conversations never had,
Yet somehow deeply etched
In the chambers of my past.

Perhaps we're just fragments
Of something vast and true,
Souls repeatedly colliding
As they're wont to do.

So let us not question
This familiar strange terrain—
For we have met before
And shall surely meet again.

We have met before
In the creases of old photographs
Never taken, yet somehow
Burned into memory's tender flesh.

I know the cadence of your laugh
Though I've never heard it ring,
And the weight of your silence
Has been my familiar ghost.

Did we pass on ancient streets
When the world was young and new?
Or share a glance across the void
Of centuries stacked between us two?

Something in your presence
Unlocks doors I never knew were there,
Corridors of recognition
Leading to rooms of answered prayer.

Perhaps our souls are travelers
On an endless cosmic wheel,
Meeting, parting, meeting again
In patterns time cannot conceal.

We have met before—
This truth I cannot shake.
In you, I find the missing piece
Of a puzzle I didn't know I make.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

responses.text:

Returning like migrant birds.

So take my hand without fear,

For in this life, as in many past,
It's you my heart still searches for.

Echoes

"We have met before," I whisper
to your silhouette against autumn light.
Not in this lifetime perhaps,
but somewhere beyond memory's reach.

Was it you who handed me water
from a clay pot in desert heat?
Or stood beside me watching
Rome's marble columns rise?

Something in your gestures speaks
of shared secrets, ancient bonds.
Your laughter triggers avalanches
of déjà vu I cannot place.

Perhaps we were comrades in war,
or rivals across royal courts,
lovers beneath different moons,
or siblings in a forgotten tongue.

The universe conspires in patterns,
souls cycling through cosmic dust.
When our eyes locked across the room,
clock hands briefly stopped their march.

"We have met before,"—not a question
but a recognition of what always was.
Two stars returning to familiar orbits,
finally remembering their ancient light.

FAMILIAR STRANGERS

We have met before—
in that space between dreaming and waking,
where reality blurs into possibility.
Your face, a watercolor painting
smudged by morning rain.

We have met before—
in crowded train stations,
breathing the same metallic air,
our shoulders nearly touching
as we rushed toward separate lives.

We have met before—
in the pages of books I've read,
your essence captured in fictional characters
who haunted me for days,
their voices echoing yours.

We have met before—
in ancestral memories,
carried through generations
in the architecture of our DNA,
ancient recognitions embedded in our cells.

We have met before—
and will meet again,
in different forms, different times,
dancing through the universe's spiral,
finding each other through cosmic coincidence.

How strange to be strangers
when our atoms have known each other
since the beginning of everything.

THREADS OF RECOGNITION

We have met before,
In some half-forgotten dream,
Where time flows like water
And nothing is as it seems.

Perhaps in a marketplace
Amid spices and silk,
Our hands briefly touching
Over fabrics smooth as milk.

Or maybe in battle,
Shields raised side by side,
Facing down our demons
With nowhere to hide.

Could it have been dancing
In candlelit halls?
Whirling through centuries
As empire walls fall?

I recognize something—
The way shadows cross your face,
How your fingers move in sunlight,
With familiar, haunting grace.

This strange recognition
Defies rational thought.
A connection transcending
What science has taught.

We have met before,
And will meet again,
Souls entwined like ivy,
Through joy and through pain.

Palimpsest

We have met before
in lives written over lives,
like ancient manuscripts
where new words rest
atop faded letters.

I see it in how you tilt your head,
the particular way light catches
your profile—a silhouette
I've known across centuries,
across countless revolutions of earth.

Perhaps we were scholars in Alexandria,
watching papyrus burn,
or pilgrims on dusty roads to Canterbury,
sharing bread and stories.

Maybe we stood together
as the Berlin Wall crumbled,
or planted rice in terraced fields
before empires had names.

The universe conserves everything—
energy, matter, souls.
Nothing truly disappears;
it only transforms, transfers,
waits to be recognized again.

So when our eyes met
across this crowded room,
time folded like origami,
and I knew: we have traveled together before,
our paths intersecting in the grand geometry
of existence's endless dance.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I saw an old cottage of clay,'

responses.text:
I saw an old cottage of clay,
With moss-covered stones and thatch gray.
Where time seemed to pause
In its relentless laws,
And memories refused to decay.

Its windows like eyes, dim with age,
Held stories on each dusty page.
Of laughter once bright,
Of fires in the night,
Of lives lived beyond history's stage.

The garden, though wild, still retained
The shape of the hands that maintained
The roses and thyme,
In some distant time,
When love in that cottage still reigned.

I touched the rough walls with my hand,
Connecting to lives long unmanned.
This humble abode,
At the end of the road,
Still stands while empires disband.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Weathered and worn by the day,
Its walls telling tales
Of storms and of gales,
Of families who'd come and who'd stay.

The chimney stood crooked but proud,
Releasing thin smoke like a shroud.
The windows, though small,
Had witnessed it all—
The whispers, both silent and loud.

Beneath ancient beams, darkened by time,
Generations had gathered to dine.
They'd laughed and they'd wept,
Their secrets they'd kept
In corners where shadows entwine.

Now nature reclaims what was built,
Vines climbing the walls without guilt.
Yet beauty remains
Despite all the stains,
Like memories preserved in a quilt.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Standing defiant against decay.
Silent guardian of yesterday's dreams,
Holding more stories than first it seems.

Its walls, though cracked, refuse to fall,
Each fissure a memory, a whispered call
From those who found shelter within its embrace,
Leaving invisible footprints, a lingering trace.

The hearth where flames once danced with glee,
Now cold as the winters it weathered free.
Yet somehow I feel their phantom heat,
As past and present mysteriously meet.

I wonder who shaped these earthen walls,
Whose laughter echoed through these halls.
Hands that mixed the clay with straw,
Creating home from earth so raw.

This humble dwelling, overlooked by most,
Stands as both shelter and silent host
To generations whose lives intertwined,
In this cottage of clay, now left behind.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Forgotten by time's hurried sway.
Its foundation embraced by roots below,
Its roof adorned with moss aglow.

The door hung loose on rusted hinge,
Creaking tales that make souls cringe
Of children's laughter, of lovers' vows,
Of hardships weathered, somehow.

Within those walls of earthen hue,
Generations lived and grew.
Simple folk with calloused hands,
Tilling nearby fertile lands.

No electricity nor modern ease,
Just firelight dancing on the breeze.
Water carried from the distant well,
Stories shared that elders tell.

I touch the wall, rough beneath my palm,
Feeling history's lingering calm.
This humble home of simple means,
Holds more truth than mansions' gleams.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
A sentinel of bygone day,
Its shoulders hunched against the wind,
Its memories neither lost nor thinned.

The hearth where once a fire burned bright,
Now cold and still in fading light.
The walls that heard a baby's cry,
Now echo only with the sigh

Of time that passes, never still,
Of seasons changing at their will.
The hands that shaped this humble home
Long turned to dust, forever roam

The fields beyond where cattle graze,
Where children played in summer haze.
The door stands open to the past,
Inviting ghosts from shadows cast.

I stand in silence, head now bowed,
Before this dwelling, humbly proud.
For in this cottage made of earth,
Lies testament to human worth.

I saw an old cottage of clay,

The cottage spoke stories to me

In this humble dwelling of soil,

I saw an old cottage of clay,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Night funeral'

responses.text:
Night Funeral

Under stars that pierce the ebony veil,
We carry what remains, our footsteps slow.
The lanterns swing, casting shadows pale,
Across the faces of those who mourn and know.

Silence wraps around us like a shroud,
Broken only by the whispered prayer.
No daylight here to make our grief less proud,
Only darkness fitting for despair.

The earth awaits, a mouth of shadow deep,
To swallow what was life and breath and song.
The night birds call as if they too must weep,
For one more soul that will not see the dawn.

We lower dreams into the waiting ground,
While midnight bells toll out their solemn sound.

Night Funeral

Black umbrellas bloom like midnight flowers,
Rain taps gentle fingers on the stone.
We gather in these hushed and sacred hours,
To face what no one wishes to face alone.

The moon, a pallbearer in silver dress,
Illuminates our procession's slow parade.
The stars bear witness to our deep distress,
As memories, like mourners, start to fade.

Candles flicker, tiny constellations,
Their light a frail defiance against the dark.
Our whispers rise like quiet incantations,
Each word a tender, temporary mark.

The night embraces both the dead and living,
In its arms, we find ourselves forgiving.

Night Funeral

The darkness holds us in its velvet hands
As we process beneath the watching moon.
Our shadows stretch across unspoken lands,
Where grief arrives both late and yet too soon.

The coffin gleams with dew and candlelight,
A vessel sailing toward the distant shore.
The world seems hushed in reverence tonight,
As one among us breathes on earth no more.

We speak in murmurs, afraid to wake the dead,
Though knowing well they'll never rise again.
The night wind carries words left unsaid,
Across the graves where memories remain.

In darkness we return them to the dust,
As stars look down on what becomes of us.

Night Funeral

They carry torches through the midnight hour,
A constellation moving through the trees.
Faces illuminated, strange with power,
As death demands us all upon our knees.

The earth is opened like a midnight wound,
A rectangle of darkness in the loam.
The hymns we sing make such a hollow sound,
As one more soul begins its journey home.

The night enfolds the ceremony tight,
No sun to sanitize our raw despair.
Only the honest judgment of starlight,
To witness how we love, and how we care.

We plant our dead beneath the watching sky,
And in that darkness, learn to say goodbye.

Night Funeral

The procession winds like a river of black,
Beneath the indifferent gaze of distant stars.
No birdsong here, no light to call us back,
Only the path that leads to where you are.

The shovel's bite against resistant soil
Echoes across the cemetery's hush.
How strange that after life's tumultuous toil,
We end in silence, stillness, and the crush

Of earth returning earth to earth again.
The candles flicker secrets to the dark.
Our breath makes ghosts that vanish in the rain,
As we stand vigil, bearing witness, stark

Against the night that claims both you and me—
One now, one later, inevitably.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Loss can be good for us,'

responses.text:
PRUNING

Loss can be good for us,
like gardeners who understand
the necessity of cutting away
what no longer serves the whole.

We shed tears like petals,
each one carrying away
a fragment of who we were,
making space for who we might become.

The orchard knows this wisdom—
trees standing stronger
after the diseased branches fall,
after the deadwood is cleared away.

I have lost love, time, certainty,
and found in their absence
a curious lightness,
an unexpected room to grow.

Perhaps we are meant to be
hollow in places,
carrying our emptiness
as vessels carry possibility.

Loss can be good for us,
a merciful pruning
that teaches us finally
the difference between
what we want
and what we need.

THE SCULPTOR'S HAND

Loss can be good for us,
the way a sculptor's chisel
removes what isn't needed,
revealing the form within.

It strips away our certainties,
those comfortable illusions
we drape around our shoulders
like well-worn winter coats.

We learn to stand naked
beneath grief's sharp gaze,
to feel the wind against
our newly exposed skin.

I have watched belongings
disappear like morning mist,
relationships dissolve
into memory's soft blur,

And found myself lighter,
more precisely defined,
a being carved down
to essential truth.

So do not fear the taking away.
The empty spaces become
resonant chambers where
new music might echo.

Loss can be good for us—
the necessary subtraction
that teaches us finally
what remains is enough.

NECESSARY WOUNDS

Loss can be good for us,
though we rarely welcome it—
this uninvited teacher
with its curriculum of absence.

It arrives like winter,
stripping trees to skeleton,
revealing architecture
we never knew was there.

I have watched possessions
slip through fingers like water,
dreams dissolve to dust,
loved ones become memory.

Each departure carves new space
inside the crowded heart,
creates room for something else:
compassion, perhaps, or wisdom.

The broken bone, they say,
heals stronger at the break.
The pruned tree bears more fruit.
The empty cup receives.

So maybe loss is not the enemy
but the necessary wound
that teaches us finally
how to live with less
and somehow become more.

SUBTRACTION'S GIFT

Loss can be good for us,
though we resist its lessons,
cling to what must go
with white-knuckled desperation.

We are collectors by nature,
gathering people, things, ideas—
building fortresses of possession
against the wilderness of uncertainty.

But what if our subtractions
are as sacred as our additions?
What if every goodbye
clears ground for new hellos?

I have surrendered dreams,
watched relationships unravel,
felt health flicker and fade,
and stood empty-handed in the aftermath.

Yet in that hollowed space
something unexpected grew:
a quiet resilience,
a deeper appreciation
for what remains.

Perhaps we need our losses
to teach us how to value,
to show us the difference
between what weighs us down

The Garden After Fire

We mourn what flames have taken—

But see—green shoots emerging

Necessary Subtraction

To shape what was remaining

So praise the painful taking,

The Sculptor's Hand

Loss can be good for us,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Prelude to "Stalky & Co."'

In hallowed halls where boyhood dreams take flight,

Prepare three boys for battles yet to drum.

In dormitories where boyhood dreams and grieves.

Existed first as ghosts in Kipling's mind.
Their pranks and plots, their righteous boyish rage,
A mirror to the man he left behind.

The chalk dust settles on the worn oak floors,
Where Empire's soldiers learn to scheme and fight.
Behind the cricket pitch and chapel doors,
The making of men happens out of sight.

This prelude hums with voices yet unheard,
With lessons taught through mischief, not through books.
The code of honor passed without a word,
In glances shared and knowing, sidelong looks.

The Masters' Lament

Before the trio's tales were fully told,
A rumbling stirred within the school's stone walls.
Young minds too clever, spirits far too bold,
Their footsteps echoing through ancient halls.

The masters sensed the coming of a storm,
In Stalky's eyes, a glint of wild design.
With M'Turk and Beetle, breaking from the norm,
Three boys whose paths would intertwine.

The Devon cliffs stood witness to their birth,
These legends forged in mischief and in wit.
Their education measured not by worth
Of books and sums, but by their ready grit.

This prelude to their storied escapades,
A warning bell for those who'd stand opposed.
For in their pranks and careful masquerades,
The Empire's future guardians were composed.

Echoes of Empire

Before the binding of those boyhood tales,
A prelude played on Devon's windswept shore,
Where college walls contained the future's trails,
And Empire's seeds were planted to the core.

Stalky and company, not yet revealed,
Were gathering their wits for battles small,
In classrooms where their fates would be annealed,
Preparing for their country's distant call.

The cricket bat, the Latin verse, the cane—
All instruments to forge the coming men,
Whose schoolboy triumphs would in time explain
The strength that guides an Empire's mighty pen.

This prelude to their chronicles of youth,
Resounds with laughter, punishment, and pride.
In Kipling's mind, already lived the truth
Of boys whose bond would never be denied.

United College

Before the ink had dried on tales untold,
Three shadows stretched across the cricket green.
A trinity of minds, both sharp and bold,

The prelude to their legend softly plays,

Where Stalky leads through labyrinthine ways,

The College stands, a fortress and a forge,

On knowledge that transforms them from the norm.

So listen close, the overture begins,
To stories woven from the threads of youth.
Of punishment and glory, loss and wins,
A testament to friendship, wit, and truth.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Hair-raising novelty;'

responses.text:
HAIR-RAISING NOVELTY

Electricity dances through my scalp,

Hair-raising novelty;

Make us feel alive again.

That gasp, that tremor, that delicious fear
That reminds us we are more than flesh.

Hair-raising novelty;
A prayer to the gods of wonder,
A plea to never grow numb
To the electric magic of being.

THE UNFAMILIAR

Hair-raising novelty;
A shiver down the spine of routine,
Where comfort curls into itself
And makes room for the strange.

I have become a collector of oddities,
Storing each peculiar moment
In jars along my windowsill,
Where sunlight makes them glitter.

The first time I tasted star anise,
The day I heard wolves howling,
When I touched the hand of someone
Whose skin felt like another language.

These encounters stand my hair on end—
Not from fear, but recognition
Of how the universe conspires
To keep us perpetually surprised.

Hair-raising novelty;
The antidote to death-before-dying,
The electric current that jolts us
Back into our bodies when we've drifted.

I welcome the unfamiliar guest,
With its strange customs and accents,
Knowing that each new wonder
Rewires the circuitry of my heart.

GOOSEBUMPS

Hair-raising novelty;
The sudden intrusion of wonder
Into the mundane landscape
Of our carefully ordered lives.

Like static electricity before a storm,
The follicles rise in anticipation,
Sensing something extraordinary
Before the mind can comprehend it.

Remember when we were children?
How everything caused this reaction—
A spider's geometric precision,
The first snowfall's silent descent,
A book that transported us elsewhere.

Now we purchase our astonishment
In carefully measured doses,
Thrill-seeking missiles aimed
At the heart of our own numbness.

Hair-raising novelty;
I'm searching for you still,
In unexpected corners and
Between the lines of familiar text.

Return to me that childhood wonder,
When my body knew before my mind
That something miraculous had arrived
To change everything forever.

THE ELECTRIC UNFAMILIAR

Hair-raising novelty;
The shock of the unforeseen
Sends currents across my skin—
A biological alarm of delight.

We are creatures of habit
Who secretly long for disruption,
For the moment when patterns break
And something extraordinary emerges.

I've felt it in foreign cities,
When street signs become hieroglyphics
And my tongue stumbles over
Syllables it wasn't born to speak.

I've known it in new love,
When familiar anatomy becomes
Unexplored territory, a map
Whose legends I must learn anew.

Hair-raising novelty;
The body's recognition that
Something significant approaches—
A primal response to the unprecedented.

May we never grow so comfortable
That we cease to seek these moments,
These electric interruptions
That remind us we are gloriously alive.

BRISTLING AWAKENING

Hair-raising novelty;
The body's first response
To something it cannot name—
A primitive alert system
That predates language.

I collect these moments
Like rare butterflies,
Pinning them carefully
To the corkboard of memory:

The first taste of wasabi,
A rollercoaster's initial drop,
The touch of lips never kissed before,
A book that reshapes reality,
Music that makes colors visible.

We are designed to notice difference,
To stand at attention when
The unfamiliar approaches.
Our hairs rise like tiny periscopes,
Scanning for danger or delight.

Hair-raising novelty;
The gateway to evolution,
For without the strange intrusion,
We would never adapt, never change,
Never know the exquisite pleasure
Of meeting something entirely new
And being forever transformed.

Where seeds of growth are sown.

Hair-raising novelty;
The unexpected guest.
The challenge to our certainties,
Life's ultimate true test.

For only in discomfort
Do we truly move ahead.

THRESHOLD CROSSING

Hair-raising novelty;
The moment just before
The plunge into cold water,
The knock upon the door.

That instant of suspension
Between the known and not,
When every cell is vibrating,
And time seems nearly stopped.

The body knows what's coming
Before the mind can speak.
The ancient warning system
That makes the future leak

Into our present moment—
A physical decree
That something transformative
Is what we're soon to see.

Hair-raising novelty;
The threshold we must cross.
The price of new beginnings,
Of gain disguised as loss.

So let your skin grow electric,
Your hairs stand proud and tall.
For this is how we recognize
Life's most important call.

BRISTLING ANTICIPATION

Hair-raising novelty;
The body's honest sign

The molecules of difference

The bristling anticipation,

Reminds us we're connected

Hair-raising novelty;
A compass for the soul.
Directing us to territories
That might just make us whole.

So honor these sensations,
The whispers of your flesh.
They speak of transformations
And worlds still fresh.

THE ELECTRIC UNFAMILIAR

BRISTLING AWAKE

FOLLICLES OF WONDER

Refreshing dawn mist, crisp air,
