They dream of harbors, safe and still,
Of houses built on solid ground.
They yearn for answers, firm and final,
For certainties that won't break down.

I've watched them build their careful lives,
Arranging days in perfect rows,
Believing peace comes wrapped in stillness,
In gardens where no wild thing grows.

But look—the eagle needs the ledge
And also needs the falling air.
The seed requires both earth and breaking,
The heart needs both love and despair.

'People wish to be settled,' it's true,
Yet settlement becomes a tomb
When walls that once protected life
Become the boundaries of a room
Too small for growing souls to breathe.

Perhaps true hope lies in between—
In learning how to build a home
With windows facing the unknown,
With doors that open to the wind,
With courage to remain unsettled
Even as we settle in.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

responses.text:
Settled Dreams

They build their houses on solid ground,
Hanging pictures on pristine walls,
They seek the comfort of the known,
As if certainty could save them from falls.

But listen—beneath that settled sigh,
A whisper of discontent remains,
For in the stillness of what's sure,
The soul finds its heaviest chains.

'People wish to be settled,' they say,
As they arrange their lives in neat rows,
Yet only in disruption's embrace
Does the seed of becoming grow.

In unsettled soil, roots reach deeper,
In unsettled minds, new thoughts bloom,
In unsettled hearts, love grows wilder,
In unsettled paths, we escape doom.

So bless the storm that breaks your shelter,
And the questions that shatter your peace,
For only as long as you're unsettled,
Will your true self find release.

The Paradox of Roots

We plant ourselves in familiar earth,
Craving the solace of routine.
Our fingers claw at permanence
While our spirits long to intervene.

'People wish to be settled,' the wise one said,
As if naming a universal disease—
This desperate clutching at stillness
When growth demands a certain unease.

The tree that never bends in wind
Snaps first when the storm arrives.
The mind that refuses to question
Is already no longer alive.

Only in the spaces between certainties
Do we discover what we might become.
Only when the ground shifts beneath us
Do we hear the universe's hum.

So cherish your moments of vertigo,
When nothing seems solid or clear.
For hope doesn't dwell in the harbor
But sails with the ships that leave here.

In unsettling, find your salvation.
In wandering, your true home awaits.
Hope lives in the courage to journey
Beyond all your settled estates.

Unsettled Blessings

Comfort wraps around us like a favorite blanket,
Seductive in its warmth, its familiar weight.
We build our walls, establish our routines,
Praying that stability will keep us safe.

'People wish to be settled,' the wisdom goes,
But settlement is where dreams ossify.
We become like artifacts in our own museums,
Preserved, perfect, and no longer alive.

It's in the earthquake of doubt
Where foundations crack and let light through.
It's in the hurricane of change
Where we discover what we can do.

The unsettled heart asks dangerous questions.
The unsettled mind creates what wasn't before.
The unsettled soul refuses the comfort
Of answers that close every door.

So bless the disruptions that shake you.
Embrace the chaos that sets you adrift.
For only as long as you're unsettled
Can hope remain your greatest gift.

In unsettlement, possibility breathes.
In unsettlement, the future is born.
In unsettlement, we remember
We were made for more than settled forms.

The Alchemy of Unrest

We build our houses brick by careful brick,
Arranging furniture just so,
Hanging our certainties on the walls
Like art that's meant for show.

How we crave the settled life—
Routines that never bend,
Beliefs that stand like monuments,
Questions that pretend to end.

But life whispers a different truth
Through cracks in what we know:
'People wish to be settled,' it says,
'Yet settlement is where hope goes to slow.'

For hope is not a garden tamed,
But wild seeds on the wind.
Hope thrives in soil that's been disturbed,
Where comfort's been rescinded.

The unsettled heart beats questions,
The unsettled mind sees new.
The unsettled soul transforms itself
Into something brave and true.

So when your world turns upside down,
When certainty takes flight,
Remember: it's in unsettling
That we find our truest light.

The Settled Illusion

We carve our names in permanent things,
Build fortresses against surprise,
We measure life in steady beats,
And call this wisdom, call this wise.

The settled life—how we pursue it!
With mortgage deeds and five-year plans,
As if by fixing all our stars
We might escape our human span.

'People wish to be settled,' the sage observed,
A truth both simple and profound,
For in that wish lies our undoing—
Hope withers in too-certain ground.

The oak that stands too rigid breaks,
While supple reeds survive the storm.
The mind that knows all answers fails
When new questions transform.

Only in the dance of doubt,
Only in the space between,
Only when we're thrown off-balance
Can we glimpse what might have been.

So bless the earthquake of change,
The lightning flash of strange new thought.
For only as long as you're unsettled
Will your spirit find what it sought.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

responses.text:
UNSETTLED GRACE

We build our homes on solid ground,
Hang pictures straight upon the wall,
As if these anchors we have found
Could halt the spinning world's mad call.

Yet in the corners of our eyes,
A restless shadow shifts and grows.
The settled heart soon ossifies,
While roots too deep refuse to grow.

'People wish to be settled,' they say,
'Only unsettled is there hope,' they know.
This paradox we live each day—
To crave both stillness and to go.

The dust that gathers speaks of time
We've stayed too long in comfort's keep.
While wild winds whisper it's no crime
To leave behind what we can't keep.

So bless the storm that shakes your door,
The doubt that makes you question why.
For only those who dare explore
Find constellations in the sky.

THE SETTLED HORIZON

We dream of harbors, safe and still,
Of foundations that will never sway.
We stack our lives like bricks until
We've walled ourselves from change away.

But listen—there's a whisper true:
'People wish to be settled,' it starts,
'Only as long as they are unsettled
Is there any hope for their hearts.'

For what is peace but death's slow twin?
What's certainty but vision's end?
The settled mind grows pale within
Its fortress built to just defend.

It's in the chaos we find grace,
In shifting sands we learn to dance.
Uncertainty makes space for faith;
Disruption gives new growth a chance.

So let your borders blur and bend,
Let questions crack your perfect shell.
The unsettled journey has no end—
In wandering, we become well.

Embracing doubt, we truly live;
In seeking, not in having found.
The greatest gift we ever give
Is staying unsettled, unbound.

SETTLED DUST

They build their houses brick by brick,
With mortgaged dreams and fenced-in yards.
The settled life, so neat and slick—
A game of safe, with wild discards.

'People wish to be settled,' they claim,
With retirement plans and scheduled days.
But souls grow dim when too tame,
Like stars that lose their cosmic blaze.

'Only as long as they are unsettled
Is there any hope for them,' the wise know.
For comfort zones become fetters,
And routine dims our inner glow.

The caterpillar, safe in its shell,
Must break apart to touch the sky.
The settled mind becomes a cell
Where dreams curl up, prepare to die.

So bless the earthquake in your plans,
The storm that floods your perfect room.
For in disruption, life expands—
In chaos, new worlds can bloom.

Unsettle me, O wind of change!
Shake loose my roots grown thick with ease.
Only in questions, wild and strange,
Can hope take flight on unsettled breeze.

UNSETTLED WATERS

We anchor boats in harbored bays,
Build fences round familiar ground.
We count success in settled ways—
In mortgages and savings sound.

'People wish to be settled,' they sigh
As they arrange their sheltered lives,
Never knowing how dreams can die
When nothing bends, when nothing strives.

'Only as long as they are unsettled
Is there any hope for them'—truth burns.
For comfort is a gilded fettle
That binds the soul that yearns.

The river stagnant grows foul and still;
The mind unchanged turns brittle, dry.
It's in the breaking of the will
That we learn how to truly fly.

The phoenix needs its burning hour,
The butterfly its chrysalis torn.
The greatest strength, the truest power
Comes when settled ways are worn.

So praise the questions, not answers firm;
Embrace the journey, not arrival's rest.
For hope lives where the unsettled yearn,
In hearts that dare the quest.

THE UNSETTLING

They build their nests with careful hands,
Arrange their lives in perfect rows—
A settled life on solid lands
Where nothing shifts and nothing grows.

'People wish to be settled,' we're told,
As if stillness were the highest prize.
But waters still soon grow old,
And settled minds soon fossilize.

'Only as long as they are unsettled
Is there any hope for them'—how strange
This wisdom cuts against the metal
Of our desperate fear of change.

For what is growth but breaking shells?
What is dawn but night disturbed?
The greatest stories history tells
Are of settled patterns curved.

The earthquake shatters, yet reveals
New passages to depths unknown.
The storm that breaks what comfort seals
Sows seeds that wouldn't else be sown.

So bless the doubt that keeps you waking,
The questions that won't let you rest.
For hope lives in the unsettled making,
Not in having, but in quest.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

responses.text:
Restless Salvation

They build their walls of certainty,

Seeking comfort in the known and safe,
While dreams lie dormant, out of range.

But listen to the whisper of the wind,
Calling to the wildness in your soul.

'People wish to be settled,' they say,

'Only as long as they are unsettled,

So embrace the chaos of becoming,

Find their wings unfurled in glorious flight.

The Comfort of Chaos

We build our nests with careful hands,
Arranging twigs of certainty,
Drawing maps with borders bold and clear,
Craving the peace of predictability.

'People wish to be settled,' the sage once said,
As we hammer nails into the floors of our days,
Hanging pictures of what we think we know,
Blind to how this settling betrays.

For only in the earthquake of doubt,

Do we find ourselves truly awakening,
From the slumber of our well-planned traps.

'Only as long as they are unsettled,

To discover the universe within,

So unsettle me, Life. Shake my ground.

For in this sacred discomfort,
Is where my soul can finally grow.

Nomads of the Soul

They long for anchors, roots, and walls,
A life where nothing ever shifts or falls.
They plant their gardens in familiar soil,
And fear the winds of change that make them toil.

But listen to what wisdom softly speaks:
'People wish to be settled,' yes, it's true,
'Only as long as they are unsettled'
Can hope's fragile seedling break through.

The caterpillar dreams of staying safe,
Never knowing wings await its form.
The ocean finds its voice in restless waves,
The diamond emerges through the storm.

So bless the questions that disturb your sleep,
The paths that lead you far from home.
Embrace the sacred art of being lost,
For only wanderers truly learn to roam.

Unsettled hearts beat with life's full measure,
Uncertain minds discover treasures new.
In the courage to remain unfinished
Lies the hope of becoming wholly true.

The Paradox of Roots

We build our houses brick by brick,

We plant our gardens, tend our fields,
And pray that nothing shifts our sight.

Yet something in us withers there,

'People wish to be settled,' yes,

'Only as long as they are unsettled,'
Can transformation truly be found.

So bless the storms that shake your core,

But in the courage to break free.

Unsettled Horizons

They long for harbors, safe and still,

They build their lives on solid ground,

Yet in this certainty they find,

'Only as long as they are unsettled,'

The river stagnant loses power,

It's in the chaos of becoming,
That our truest selves are made.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I walk alone, I think of you my love'

responses.text:
When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
Your smile that brightens up my darkest day.
Your voice, a gentle whisper from above,
Guiding me along my solitary way.

Footsteps echo on the empty street,
Memories of you flood into my mind.
The phantom pressure of your hand I greet,
A love so pure and rare, so hard to find.

The evening sky transforms before my eyes,
Painting colors that remind me of your grace.
In every star, I see your sparkling eyes,
In every cloud, the softness of your face.

Alone I walk, but never truly so,
For in my heart, you're with me as I go.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love
Footprints in sand that time will wash away
Yet memories persist like treasured gloves
Worn thin with use but warming still today

The city streets become a wilderness
Where echoes of your laughter guide me home
Each corner holds a fragment of your kiss
Each lamppost marks where we would often roam

The weight of absence heavy as the moon
That pulls the tides and draws my heart to shore
I count the steps until we meet again too soon
Is never soon enough when hearts implore

When I walk alone, I'm never truly so
Your spirit walks beside me, don't you know?

When I walk alone, I think of you my love
Through autumn leaves and winter's bitter chill
Your phantom hand in mine, like hand in glove
A presence that both time and space can't kill

The world around me fades to background noise
As memories of you flood every sense
Your laughter cuts through strangers' empty joys
And wraps around my heart in sweet defense

I see your face in every passing cloud
I hear your voice in every songbird's tune
The wind that whispers softly or aloud
Reminds me we'll be reunited soon

This solitude is merely temporal space
For in my soul, you occupy each place
When I walk alone, I'm never truly so
For you, my love, are where my heart calls home.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love
Beneath the endless canvas of the sky
Where scattered stars like memories above
Illuminate the paths where dreams may lie

The rhythm of my footsteps marks the time
Since last your hand was gently clasped in mine
Each heartbeat forms a melancholy rhyme
A poem written on the sands of time

The trees stand witness to my silent prayer
Their branches reaching like my thoughts to you
The wind that whispers secrets through my hair
Carries my longing, tender, deep and true

Though separate we wander different lands
Our souls remain entwined like braided strands.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
Across the chasm time has carved between
Our separate worlds. The skies stretch far above,
Reflecting all the places we have been.

Your absence walks beside me like a ghost,
A shadow self that never leaves my side.
Of all the things I've lost, I miss you most—
The tide recedes, but love does not subside.

The city streets transform to memory lanes,
Each corner holds the echo of your name.
Through sunshine bright or cold November rains,
My heart beats out your rhythm just the same.

Alone I wander through these mortal days,
Yet never truly solo in these ways—
For in the space between each breath I take,
Your love remains, a promise we won't break.

ECHOES OF ABSENCE

WALKING REVERIES

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,

The distant church bells toll our sacred hours,

Street lamps illuminate what isn't there,

FOOTSTEPS IN TIME

The moon that hangs so patiently above

I count my steps like heartbeats in the night,

The city sleeps, yet stars provide the light

Remembrance paints your portrait in the air,
Your voice rides softly on the evening breeze.
I feel your presence everywhere I fare,
In summer blooms and winter-barren trees.

Though solitary walks may fill my days,
My thoughts of you transform these lonely ways.

Yet in this quiet, your voice is found.

The autumn leaves that crackle 'neath my feet
Remind me of the pages we once turned,
Each step becomes a heartbeat, incomplete,
A rhythm of the lessons we have learned.

The distant hills that fade to purple hue
Mirror the way you softly disappear,
Not gone completely, just beyond my view,
Somehow both impossibly far and near.

These solitary paths I often roam
Carry your essence in the wind's soft song,
Whispers that guide me gently toward home,
Where memories of us have belonged all along.

ECHOES IN SOLITUDE

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
The pavement stretches endlessly ahead.
The city hums with life I'm nothing of,
As memories of you fill me instead.

Street lamps illuminate my lonely way,
Like spotlights on the stage of my regret.
The shadows dance with ghosts of yesterday,
Performing scenes my heart cannot forget.

Rain falls like tears upon my upturned face,
Each droplet carries whispers of your name.
I search for you in every empty space,
Though knowing you and I aren't the same.

The universe expands between our touch,
Vast galaxies of silence and of time.
I never thought that I could miss so much,
The simple way your fingers linked with mine.

When I walk alone, I'm never truly so—
Your memory walks faithfully beside.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love
Across the shifting sands of measured time
Your absence tangible as morning dove
That sings but stays beyond my reach sublime

The pebbled path beneath these wandering feet
Bears witness to my solitary quest
Each step a heartbeat, rhythmic and complete
Yet hollow in its singular unrest

The trees that line my journey seem to bend
As if to whisper secrets you once shared
The wind carries your laughter round each bend
Reminding me of moments that we paired

I gather fallen blossoms as I go
Collecting fragments of what cannot last
Like memories that shimmer, ebb and flow
Between the present moment and the past

When I walk alone, I'm never truly so
For you inhabit every breath I take.

So as I wander through these quiet streets,

SOLITARY WANDERINGS

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,

The cobblestones remember our shared steps,

I gather fragments of our bygone days,

PHANTOM COMPANION

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,

I pass the café where we used to sit,

The streetlights flicker on like distant stars,

Each corner holds a fragment of our tale,

So let me wander through these lonely streets,

FOOTPRINTS IN TIME

The world seems dimmer in these solitary hours,

I pass the park where we once gathered flowers,

The rhythm of my footsteps keeps the time,

The distance stretches like a weary road,

So though I walk these paths in solitude,

SHADOWS AND LIGHT

The evening gathers shadows at my feet,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough'

responses.text:
ECHOES OF BURNS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Pressed close to hear the lilting verse,
Their calloused hands and faces tough
Softened as words began to nurse
The wounds that daily labor wrought.

These men of soil and sweat and stone,
Whose backs were bent by ceaseless toil,
Found in those verses not their own
A truth that made their spirits roil
With recognition, raw and real.

For Burns knew well the common soul,
The dignity in humble ways.
He made the fractured heart feel whole
Through honest words and measured phrase
That honored lives deemed ordinary.

So gathered they, these working hands,
Around the voice that spoke of him,
The poet who helped them understand
That worth runs deeper than life's grim
Exterior of struggle and strife.

THE BARD'S DEVOTEES

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Leaned forward on their weathered chairs,
Their whiskey glasses, nearly empty now,
Caught firelight in amber snares.

These men whose hands told stories—
Ridged with scars from honest labor,
Calloused monuments to years
Of wrestling life from unyielding earth—

Found gentleness in verses
That gave voice to silent struggles.
They nodded, these titans of the field,
As Burns' words flowed through another's lips.

How strange that poetry should move
These mountains made of flesh,
These giants who rarely spoke of love
Or pain or hope or death.

Yet here they sat, transformed,
Their rough-hewn faces soft with wonder,
For Burns had walked their paths before
And turned their lives to song.

ROUGH HANDS, TENDER HEARTS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Circled round like moths to flame,
Their Scottish hearts, though dark and gruff,
Knew every line, recalled each name
That danced through Robert's verses.

These men of mine and mill and farm,
With dirt-etched lines on sun-worn faces,
Found in poetry a curious charm,
A respite from life's harsher places,
A mirror for their unspoken yearning.

Their laughter—coarse as granite—broke
When Burns' wit skewered pompous lords.
Their eyes shone damp when someone spoke
Of love and loss in simple words
That made the universal personal.

How strange to see such hardened souls
Transformed by rhythm, rhyme, and meter,
As if the bard himself controls
The hearts of men—no victory sweeter
Than art that bridges rough and gentle.

THE PLOWMAN'S VERSE

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Gathered close with reverent eyes,
Their voices—normally so gruff—
Fell silent under evening skies
As words of one who knew them well
Began to weave their magic spell.

These hands that broke the stubborn earth,
These backs bent low by thankless toil,
These souls who questioned their own worth
Found validation in the soil
Of Burns' verse—where honest labor
Stood equal to a king's own saber.

The tavern's smoke hung thick as wool
Around their heads like thoughts made visible,
While hearts deemed simple, hearts deemed dull
Proved capable of things ineffable—
For in each rough-hewn, calloused palm
Lay dreams that Burns' words could embalm.

He spoke of Burns, and in that speech
The common man found dignity,
Discovered truths within their reach
And glimpsed their own divinity.

KINDRED SPIRITS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Fell silent in the tavern's glow.
Their daily bread earned hard enough,
Yet poetry, they came to know,
Could feed a hunger deeper still.

These men with hands like knotted oak,
With faces carved by wind and sun,
Found in the verses that he spoke
A battle they had fought and won—
The struggle to be seen as whole.

For Burns had walked behind the plow,
Had felt the soil between his fingers,
Had wiped the sweat from furrowed brow,
And in his words, that knowledge lingers—
The dignity of common labor.

They nodded as the speaker read,
These men unschooled in lettered arts,
For though their hands were rough, 'tis said
That Burns had captured all their hearts
By singing what they could not say.

How strange that verse could bridge the gap
Between the learned and the plain,
And in that moment's gentle trap,
All men were equal once again,
United by a poet's vision.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough'

responses.text:
THE ROUGH-HEWN POET

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough

The plowman-poet's humble song

In taverns dim where shadows dance,
The common folk with common dreams
Found in his rhymes a second chance,
A truth that's deeper than it seems.

For Burns knew well the human heart,
Its struggles, joys, and deep despair.
He stripped pretension's mask apart
And found the soul laid naked there.

So speak of Burns, of men like him,
Whose roughness hides a gentle core.
The stars shine brightest when most dim
The night that holds them, evermore.

ROUGH HANDS, TENDER WORDS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Gathered around the hearth's warm glow,
With weathered faces, stern and gruff,
Their eyes alight with inner know.

These men of soil and stone and steel,
With hands that bled from honest toil,
Found in his verse a way to feel
The beauty growing from the soil.

They recognized the humble truth
That flowed like whisky from his pen,
The dignity of age and youth
Captured in stanzas now and then.

For Burns spoke not of kings and queens
But of the mouse, the louse, the poor,
The everyday, the in-betweens,
The lives that others would ignore.

So raise a glass to those rough men
Who found themselves in lyric line,
And to the bard whose Scottish pen
Made common lives appear divine.

THE PLOUGHMAN'S AUDIENCE

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Leaned forward on their wooden chairs,
Their faces etched by weather tough,
Their souls worn thin by worldly cares.

The tavern's smoke hung thick as wool
As verses pierced the hazy air,
And hearts once empty, now grew full
Of words that made the coarsest share

A tender thought, a gentle sigh,
A longing for some higher truth.
These men who never questioned why
Their lives seemed spent without reproof

Found in the ploughman's simple rhyme
A mirror to their unsung worth,
A testament that stood through time
That heaven might be found on earth.

For Burns, though from their rugged ranks,
Gave voice to what they could not say—
That dignity deserves our thanks
In lives of labor, night and day.

KINDRED SPIRITS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Sat silently with brimming eyes,
Their outer shells seemed cold and tough,
Yet poetry had pierced disguise.

The farmer's son who sang of mice,
Of daisies crushed beneath the plow,
Of freedom worth the highest price,
Of love that makes the poorest bow.

These men of mountain, mine, and moor,
With hands like leather, voices deep,
Found kinship with the Scottish poor
Whose truths made mighty landlords weep.

For what is roughness but a shield
Against a world that seldom cares?
Beneath, the tenderest hearts concealed,
A wealth of feeling no one shares.

So Burns remains their brother still,
Across the centuries of change.
His verses climb each rugged hill
Where working souls may find their range.

THE BARD'S COMPANY

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
With whisky breath and mud-caked boots,
Their language raw, their manner gruff,
Yet wisdom flowed from humble roots.

The tavern walls absorbed their talk
Of honest toil and simple needs,
Of how a poet chose to walk
Among the common folk and weeds.

No ivory tower could contain
The verses born of Scotland's soil,
Distilled from joy and human pain,
And sanctified by honest toil.

These men, though strangers to the page,
Could quote his lines with perfect heart,
For Burns had turned their quiet rage
To something closer to high art.

So when they speak of Burns tonight,
Remember well these men uncouth,
Whose roughened hands held candle-light
To find in darkness, beauty's truth.

When polished society disdained.

And as he spoke, I came to see
That roughness hides a gentle art—
The raw, unvarnished honesty
That beats within the human heart.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Die because a woman's fair?
Or make pale my cheeks with care
Because another's rosy are?

No, the stars that guide my path
Burn despite the coming dawn,
And I too shall persevere
When hope seems all but gone.

Shall I turn my spirit low
When shadows stretch across my days?
Or let my inner fire dim
When fortune turns her gaze?

I'll stand against the tides of time,
Embrace both joy and pain,
For wasting in despair yields naught
But moments lived in vain.

Shall I wasting in despair
Cling to ghosts of yesterday?
Chains of memory, heavy-worn,
Dragging footsteps led astray.

Embers of what once burned bright
Scattered now like autumn leaves.
Yet within this hollow chest,
A stubborn heart still beats, still grieves.

Shall I wasting in despair
Surrender to the darkened sky?
Or rise like phoenix from these flames,
Reborn through tears I've yet to cry?

I choose to walk through valleys deep,
To scale the mountains of my fear.
For in despair's relentless grip,
I've found the strength to persevere.

Shall I wasting in despair
Count the hours 'til morning light?
While shadows dance across the wall
And stars fade from my sight?

The clock ticks on relentlessly,
Each moment slips away.
Yet here I sit in solitude,
A prisoner of yesterday.

Shall I surrender to the void
That threatens to consume?
Or kindle flames of courage
To illuminate the gloom?

Perhaps in this dark reckoning
A truth begins to form—
That wasting in despair denies
The chance to weather storm.

So I shall rise and face the dawn,
Embrace what lies ahead.
For even in my darkest hour,
Hope whispers to be fed.

Shall I wasting in despair
Bend beneath grief's heavy weight?
Drowning in these bitter tears
As seconds turn to fate?

The mirror shows a stranger now,
Hollow-eyed and worn,
A shell of former glory days
When joy was freely born.

Yet somewhere in this wilderness,
A voice begins to call—
Reminding me that stronger souls
Have risen from their fall.

The path ahead lies shrouded still
In mist I cannot part,
But forward steps, however small,
Reveal a healing heart.

Shall I wasting in despair?
No—I choose to rise instead.
For even in the darkest night,
Stars guide the path ahead.

Shall I wasting in despair
Surrender to the night?
While dreams lie broken at my feet
And stars withhold their light?

The world spins on indifferent
To one heart's mournful cry,
And time—that cruel physician—
Offers no reason why.

Yet in this desolation
A seedling truth takes root:
That sorrow's soil, though bitter now,
May yield the sweetest fruit.

The universe in wisdom
Withholds what I would see:
That through this crucible of pain
A stronger self breaks free.

So shall I waste in dark despair?
I think not, though tears fall.
For in this sacred suffering
I hear my spirit's call.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Die because a woman's fair?
Or make pale my cheeks with care
Cause another's rosy are?
Be she fairer than the day,
Or the flow'ry meads in May,
If she be not so to me,
What care I how fair she be?

Shall my heart be torn asunder
By the weight of constant wonder?
Shall I chase the fleeting light
Through the darkness of my night?
Stars may fall and mountains crumble,
Oceans rise and cities tumble,
Yet I stand amid the storm,
Neither broken nor forlorn.

Despair is but a passing cloud,
A whisper in a screaming crowd.
I choose to rise above the pain,
To dance defiantly in rain.

Shall I wasting in despair
Count the hours that lead nowhere?
Measure time in silent tears
As the darkness perseveres?

No—I'll rise from ashen ground
Where my hopes were once unbound.
From the embers of my grief
I shall craft a new belief.

Despair may cloak my weary frame
But cannot quench my inner flame.
Through valleys deep and mountains steep
A stronger self emerges from sleep.

The void that threatened to consume
Becomes the womb of light and bloom.
What was once a prison cell
Transforms to wings on which I dwell.

Shall I wasting in despair?
No, I choose the open air.
From the depths I now ascend,
Broken pieces I shall mend.

Shall I wasting in despair
When stars still glimmer everywhere?
Though shadows lengthen on my path,
And winter brings its aftermath,

I'll not surrender to the night
That seeks to dim my inner light.
For in the darkness, seeds take root,
And silence bears the sweetest fruit.

Despair, that thief of precious time,
Would have me believe the upward climb
Is futile as the changing tide—
A battle lost before I've tried.

Yet something whispers through the gloom,
A gentle voice dispelling doom:
"The heart that breaks a thousand ways
Finds strength to mend in coming days."

So shall I waste these hours in vain
Or dance defiantly through rain?
I choose to seek the hidden door
That leads to what's worth living for.

Shall I wasting in despair
Sink beneath the weight of care?
Shall I let my spirit drown
In the sea where hopes all frown?

The clock ticks on without consent
As I ponder what is meant
By this hollow ache inside—
This void where dreams have died.

Yet even as the shadows grow
And bitter winds begin to blow,
I feel a spark refuse to die,
A stubborn flame that questions why.

Perhaps in darkness most complete
The light's return is twice as sweet.
Perhaps in emptiness profound
The fullness of life can be found.

Shall I wasting in despair?
No—I'll breathe the morning air,
Plant my feet on solid ground,
And let my broken voice resound.

Shall I wasting in despair
Cling to ghosts no longer there?
Shall I count each passing day
As treasures slipping fast away?

The mirror shows a face worn thin
By battles fought but cannot win,
Yet somewhere deep beneath the skin
A different story waits within.

Despair, that patient predator,
Would make of me its prisoner—
A captive to what might have been,
To doors unopened, sights unseen.

But even in the darkest hour
When clouds of doubt begin to tower,
The smallest seed contains the power
To break concrete and still flower.

So shall I waste away in grief
Or turn the page to find relief?
I choose the path less traveled by:
To live, to grow, to testify.

responses.text:

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's own treasure, now departed hence.
Like autumn leaves that fall and then destroy
The summer's memory with their innocence.

Your laughter echoes still within these walls,
Your footprints fade upon the garden path.
The silence of your absence loudly calls
Across the chasm of time's aftermath.

I held you once, so small within my palm,
A miracle of life, of hope renewed.
Now memory alone provides the balm
For wounds that time has never quite subdued.

So go, my child, into the waiting world,
With wings unfurled and spirit ever bright.
Though distance grows as years become unfurled,
You remain forever in my heart's sight.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The vessel of my hopes now sailing far.
Time's tide has carried you beyond my reach,
A distant star.

I remember when you first drew breath,
Tiny fingers clutching at my own.
Now you walk a path I cannot follow,
Fully grown.

The nursery stands empty, toys at rest,
Dust gathering on books once read by night.
The silence speaks of what has been released—
Your upward flight.

Nature's law demands this separation,
As saplings must outgrow the parent tree.
Yet in this parting lives a celebration
Of what will be.

So go forth boldly into dawning day,
Carry with you all I tried to teach.
My love remains your anchor and your compass,
Beyond speech.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Such tender fruit plucked early from life's tree.
The heavens claim what earth could not destroy—
A soul too pure for mortal eyes to see.

I traced your features in the morning light,
Memorized the rhythm of your breath.
Now phantom touches haunt my restless night,
A love that transcends boundaries of death.

The cradle rocks, yet empty is its hold;
The lullaby dies softly on my lips.
Your memory—more precious than fine gold—
Remains as stars emerge when daylight slips.

Though grief may bend me like a willow bough,
And tears may water fields where you once played,
I'll find the strength to carry onward now,
Emboldened by the light your brief life made.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's best chapter, written then erased.
Like morning mist that sunlight must destroy,
Your presence fades, though never quite effaced.

The world turns colder in your absence now,
As winter follows summer's vibrant reign.
I search for reasons, wondering how
Such partings can be anything but pain.

Yet in this hollow space you leave behind,
A strange new wisdom gradually appears.
The love we shared, not limited by time,
Outlasts the counting of remaining years.

Perhaps in losing what I held most dear,
I learn at last what it has meant to give
A piece of soul, a fragment crystal-clear,
That in another heart continues to live.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My flesh and blood now venturing alone.
The years between us stretch like seas deployed
Between two shores that once were closely sewn.

I watch you shrink against the horizon's edge,
Your silhouette a memory in making.
No longer do you need my sheltering hedge;
Your roots now seek new soil for your taking.

The house grows quiet in your swift retreat,
Each room an echo chamber of the past.
The table setting absent of your seat
Reminds me nothing mortal is built to last.

Yet in this parting lives a secret grace—
The fullest measure of a parent's pride.
To see you claim your rightful, distant place
Among the stars that now become your guide.

The stars shine colder in your absence now,

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:

Farewell, sweet child, my joy, my all;

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;

I carved your name in bark of ancient trees,

Your ghost now dances with the autumn leaves,

The instruments we bought collect their dust,

Now haunt these halls with silence so unjust,
The music of what might have been someday.

I gather trinkets that you left behind—

Small treasures of a brilliant, untamed mind
That never had the chance to come of age.

So fare thee well, my child, my heart, my light;
Though grief may bend me like a weathered oak,
I'll keep your memory burning through the night,
Until my own last ember has been stoked.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
No longer shall I watch you learn and grow.
Time's cruel scissors cut our thread, destroy
The tapestry we'd only just begun to sow.

Your eyes, those mirrors of unblemished soul,
Reflected back a world still new and bright.
Now darkness claims that luminescent whole,

I gather up your trinkets, small and dear—
A wooden horse, a book with tattered spine,
A tiny shoe that you'll no longer wear,
These relics of a life cut out of time.

The seasons turn with indifferent grace,
As nature cares not for our human pain.
The world spins on, leaving empty space
Where once your laughter fell like gentle rain.

Farewell, sweet child, though parting breaks my core;
Your spirit dances free beyond my reach.
I stand bereaved upon this mortal shore,
While you explore the stars I cannot breach.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The universe reclaims its borrowed light.
Like petals scattered when the winds employ

I trace the echo of your gentle breath,

No wisdom reconciles this early death,
No words can heal where deepest sorrow looms.

The books we'd planned to read collect their dust,

Your future dreams now crumbled into rust,
The lessons you would never live to learn.

Yet in the garden where your ashes rest,
New blossoms push through soil with quiet might.
Perhaps in them, your spirit manifests—
Transformed but never vanished from my sight.

So though I weep beneath the weight of loss,
And though my arms feel hollow without you,
I'll carry on, despite this heavy cross,
And find you in all beautiful and true.

Could carve such chasms of absence in my soul.

The seasons turn without you, sunlight falls
On gardens where you'll never place your steps.
I hold your memory like a folded note,
Preserved between the pages of my days.

Farewell, sweet promise, unrealized and pure,
My love for you transcends this mortal sphere.
Though you depart before your story blooms,
Your brief existence changed my world complete.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My tender sapling torn from earthly soil.
The universe reclaims its borrowed light,
And I am left in shadows, incomplete.

What cosmic law demands such painful trade?
A parent's heart for fleeting glimpse of grace?
Your spirit, like a comet, blazed so bright,
Then vanished beyond mortal reach or gaze.

I held you once against my beating chest,
Your tiny fingers wrapped around my own.
Now empty hands grasp only at the wind,
And memories that slowly fade like dew.

The world moves forward, heedless of my grief,
While I remain tethered to that moment,
When you were here, alive within my arms,
Before the heavens called you back again.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Departing like the twilight's fading glow.
No longer shall I guide your tender steps,
Or watch your mind unfurl like spring's first bloom.

The pen that wrote your name now writes goodbye,
Ink flowing dark as tears upon the page.
What verses might we crafted, you and I,
Had fate allowed our stories more to share?

I send you forth with blessings, not with chains,
Though every fiber yearns to hold you close.
The world awaits your singular design,
Your voice, your vision, wholly yours alone.

Remember sometimes this old poet's love,
When distant stars remind you of your home.
For though we part, our souls remain entwined,
Across the vast expanses of this life.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's reflection, fragment of my soul.
The cord that bound us, severed by cold fate,
Leaves phantom pain where once connection lived.

I watched you grow from helpless, mewling babe
To bright-eyed wonder, questioning the world.
Your mind unfurled like petals to the sun,
Absorbing light and knowledge with such thirst.

Now destiny has called you from my side,
To paths I cannot follow nor protect.
The silence in these rooms speaks volumes now,
Each empty space a monument to loss.

Yet in this grief, a stubborn hope remains:
That all I've given serves as lantern flame,
Illuminating roads when night descends,
My love, a compass pointing you toward home.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Whose breath was sweeter than spring's gentle breeze.
Death's shadow fell too soon upon your brow,
And stole what time had promised would be mine.

I carved your name in bark of ancient trees,
That something of your essence might endure.
The birds that sing at dawn now sound your name,
The evening stars reflect your vanished light.

How strange that arms once filled now cradle air,
That silence roars where laughter used to reign.
I search for meaning in this emptiness,
This void that weighs more heavy than the earth.

Yet somewhere past the veil of mortal sight,
Perhaps your spirit dances, truly free.
And I, still bound by flesh and memory,
Await reunion on that distant shore.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's own treasure, now departed hence.
Like autumn leaves that fall from branch to sky,
You've left me here in solemn recompense.

The cradle where I rocked your infant form
Stands empty now, a monument to time.
Your laughter, once my shelter from the storm,
Echoes only in this grieving rhyme.

I held you close within my trembling palm,
A fragile bird with wings not yet unfurled.
Your presence was my spirit's sweetest balm,
A gift too briefly lent unto this world.

So go, my child, into that distant light,
While I remain in memory's embrace.
The stars shall guide your everlasting flight,
Until we meet in time's appointed place.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Sunlight captured in mortal form.
Your spirit, like the falcon's swift deploy,
Soars beyond the reach of earthly storm.

I trace the memory of your gentle face,
Etched in mind like scripture carved in stone.
The hollow echo of your vacant space
Resounds in chambers where my grief has grown.

What cosmic debt demanded payment due
That heaven should reclaim its borrowed star?
The universe, reshaped without you,
Seems dimmer, colder, stranger than before.

Yet in the garden where your footprints rest,
Wildflowers bloom with unexpected grace.
Perhaps in this, I'm momentarily blessed—
A whispered promise I shall once embrace
Your soul again, beyond time's measured race.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Departed like the morning dew at dawn.
The world spins on its axis, cold, aloof,
Unmindful of the treasure it has drawn
Back to the silence whence all life begins.

I watch the empty spaces where you moved,
The chair still warm with imprints of your form.
The books whose pages felt your gentle touch
Now gather dust, their stories left unwarm.

How strange that atoms scattered through the void
Should gather once to shape your precious face,
Then scatter once again like stars at flight,
Leaving nothing but this aching space.

Yet in my dreams you visit, whole and bright,
A phantom blessing in the dead of night.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My compass and my guiding northern star.
Time's merciless current carries you away
To shores unseen, beyond the harbor bar.

The house grows silent with your absence now;
No footfalls on the stairs, no doors ajar.
The rooms that held your laughter, sealed somehow,
Preserving echoes of the child you are.

I planted seeds of wisdom in your soul,
And watched them bloom in ways I could not plan.
You grew beyond the garden of my hopes
Into a forest I cannot command.

So spread your wings against the waiting sky,
Embrace the winds that call you to your flight.
Though tears may cloud the vision of my eye,
My heart beholds your journey with delight.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Whose breath was sweeter than spring's first caress.
The clockwork of my heart winds down in grief,
As shadows lengthen where your light once blessed
The common air made sacred by your being.

I gather memories like fallen leaves—
Your first uncertain steps across the floor,
Your voice that sang the world to newness,
Your eyes that saw what I had missed before.

The cosmos shifts its patterns in your wake;
The moon hangs differently against the night.
Even stars seem dimmer in their course,
As if they too must mourn your early flight.

Yet somewhere in the tapestry of time,
Your thread continues, golden, unconfined.
Perhaps we'll meet where all rivers climb
Back to the source that birthed all humankind.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:
In my first sleep
I drift through velvet darkness,
A voyager in realms unseen by day.
Memories dissolve like morning dew,
As consciousness surrenders to the deep.

In my first sleep
The world's sharp edges soften,
Time stretches like taffy pulled by gentle hands.
Worries that plagued me at dusk
Now seem distant as forgotten stars.

In my first sleep
I hear the universe breathing,
Its cosmic lullaby surrounds my being.
I am both nothing and everything,
A particle of dust and the entire cosmos.

In my first sleep
I find the truths that daylight blinds,
Wisdom that hides from waking eyes.
For in surrender comes revelation,
In darkness blooms the clearest light.

In my first sleep
I wandered through gardens of starlight,
Where dreams bloomed like midnight flowers.
The weight of the day had melted away,
Leaving only the essence of being.

Shadows danced across my closed eyelids,
Telling stories of ancient worlds,
Of loves lost and found again
In the tender embrace of slumber.

In my first sleep
I heard the whispers of my ancestors,
Their voices carried on currents of time,
Wisdom passed through generations
To rest gently upon my dreaming mind.

The universe expanded within me,
And I within it—boundless, free.
In my first sleep, I discovered
That consciousness has no borders,
That the soul roams where the body cannot.

And when dawn's fingers reached for me,
I carried back treasures from that sacred realm,
Holding tight to visions that daylight tries to steal.

In my first sleep
The world falls away like autumn leaves,
Gently descending into forgotten corners.
I am adrift on an ocean of possibility,
Neither here nor there, but somewhere in between.

Quiet whispers of half-formed thoughts
Dance through the corridors of my mind,
Leaving footprints that will vanish by morning.
Time becomes elastic, stretching and contracting
With each slow, dreambound breath.

In my first sleep
I meet myself as stranger and as friend,
Faces I've worn and those I've yet to try on.
The universe contracts to a single point
Then expands beyond all knowing.

Memories blend with wishes,
Fears transform to wondrous flights,
And the boundaries between what was
And what could be dissolve like sugar in rain.

In my first sleep
I am closest to truth,
That ephemeral moment when consciousness
Surrenders to the deeper knowing
That lives beneath the surface of our days.

In my first sleep
I shed the skin of daylight hours,
Slipping into the cool waters of oblivion.
The chattering mind grows quiet,
As thoughts dissolve like sugar in warm tea.

In my first sleep
I am neither who I was
Nor who I will become with morning's light.
I exist in the in-between spaces,
Where reality bends and time loses meaning.

The universe breathes with me,
Expanding with each inhalation,
Contracting as I release.
Stars pulse in rhythm with my heart,
And distant galaxies echo my dreams.

In my first sleep
I remember ancient wisdoms
Carried in the marrow of my bones.
Secrets whispered by ancestors
Whose blood still sings in my veins.

This sacred twilight realm
Holds truths that daylight blinds.
In my first sleep,
I touch the face of eternity
And for a moment, understand everything.

In my first sleep
The world dissolves like watercolors in rain,
Edges blurring, colors bleeding
Into one another until nothing remains
But impression and feeling.

Time loses its tyrannical grip.
I float between moments,
Neither bound by yesterday's regrets
Nor tomorrow's anxieties.
Just the endless now of dreaming.

In my first sleep
I hear music that has no source—
Melodies composed of starlight and shadow,
Rhythms that match the beating of hearts
Across centuries and continents.

Faces appear like photographs developing,
Some I know, others I've never seen
Yet somehow recognize as my own.
We speak in languages without words,
Understanding perfectly in the logic of dreams.

In my first sleep
I remember what it is to be infinite,
To exist beyond flesh and bone.
And though morning will claim me,
These midnight revelations remain,
Like salt on skin after swimming in the sea.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:

In my first sleep, time dissolves,

In my first sleep, I understand

In my first sleep, I find the truth

The wisdom of eternal youth,
In dreamscape finally revealed.

In my first sleep, shadows dance
Across the ceiling of my mind,
Weaving tapestries of forgotten dreams
And half-remembered lullabies.

The world grows quiet, save for
The steady drumbeat of my heart,
A metronome marking passage
Into realms beyond consciousness.

In my first sleep, I am ageless,
Floating between what was and what could be,
Untethered from the anchors of day,
Free to explore the vastness within.

Voices call from distant shores,
Familiar yet strange, like echoes
Of conversations never had,
With people I've always known.

In my first sleep, I touch the face
Of my own mortality, gently,
Acknowledging the temporary nature
Of breath, of thought, of being.

And in this sacred space between
Wakefulness and deep slumber,
I glimpse, if only for a moment,
The infinite universe contained in a single heartbeat.

In my first sleep, worlds unfold
Like origami creatures taking flight.
The boundaries of flesh dissolve

The day's harsh edges soften here

Old memories resurface clear,

In my first sleep, I often meet
Versions of myself I've never known—
The child I was, with running feet,
The elder I'll become, wise-grown.

Sometimes I walk through doorways bright
To landscapes painted in impossible hues.
Where gravity holds no certain might

In my first sleep, truth reveals
Its naked face without disguise.
What waking hours conceal,
Lies open under dreaming skies.

This twilight realm between two worlds

As reality gently unfurls,
I learn life's deepest lessons.

In my first sleep, I drift away
On currents warm and deep,
Where consciousness begins to fray
And secrets long to leap.

The burden of the day now shed
Like autumn's fading leaves,
As thoughts unravel in my head
And fantasy interweaves.

In this half-light of the mind
Where logic starts to bend,
I leave the waking world behind
And greet night as a friend.

Images float, untethered, free,
Disconnected from their source.
Fragments of reality
Charge down an unknown course.

In my first sleep, I often find
The answers that elude
My waking, searching, restless mind
In daylight's amplitude.

This threshold state, this borderland
Between the dark and light,
Holds wisdom I can't understand
When day is at its height.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,'

responses.text:
IRON TRAJECTORY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A steel-tipped harbinger of dawn's uncertain light.
Its whistle pierces silence, the sleeping world startling,
As wheels on rails create a rhythm through the night.

Cutting through landscapes hidden beneath midnight's veil,
Carrying dreams and dreamers to destinations unknown.
Windows aglow like fireflies that never fail,
Connecting separate lives that might have never grown.

This mechanical comet with its tail of smoke and spark,
Thunders between the void of stars and earthly ground.
A momentary constellation moving through the dark,
Bringing distant horizons suddenly profound.

How strange to be suspended in this rushing space,
Between departures and arrivals, lost in time's embrace.

MIDNIGHT PASSAGE

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Slicing night's fabric with its determined steel head.
Passengers rock gently, some sleeping, some departing
From lives they knew, to futures filled with hope or dread.

The countryside flies past in shadowed silhouettes,
Trees, hills, and houses—mere ghosts against the sky.
The rhythm of the tracks lays down a song of regrets
And possibilities that make the heart reply.

We are all arrows shot from bows we cannot see,
Hurtling toward targets that shift with every mile.
The journey transforms us, though we may disagree,
As landscapes change our vision, thought by thought, meanwhile.

The darkness holds its secrets close as we pass through,
This metal vessel carrying stories old and new,
And when dawn breaks upon our travel-weary eyes,
We'll be different arrows under different skies.

VELOCITY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Piercing the velvet curtain of the midnight hour.
A mechanical beast, relentless, always starting
Journeys that bend both time and space with thunderous power.

I press my face against cold glass, watching shadows race,
Reflections of my features ghost against the black.
The world outside—a blur of speed, a nameless place
Where memories and futures intertwine and track.

What destinations wait beyond this rushing void?
What lives unfold in pinprick lights we hurtle past?
The carriage sways like pendulums, dreams deployed
Across the distance where our fates are cast.

We are all travelers shot through existence's night,
Momentary streaks of consciousness in flight,
Connected by these rails of circumstance and chance,
Darting arrows in time's mysterious dance.

NIGHT TRAJECTORY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Carving tunnels through the fabric of the night.
The passengers within, their journeys now imparting
Tales untold, as windows frame the absent light.

The rhythmic clacking speaks in ancient code,
A heartbeat of the modern world in steel and steam.
Beneath the stars we follow this determined road,
Suspended between reality and dream.

Outside, the world retreats in blurred obscurity,
Trees and fields and houses flash then disappear.
Inside, strangers share this metal cavity,
Each carrying stories that nobody will hear.

How swift we move through darkness toward the dawn,
Like thoughts across the mind that linger, then are gone.
This arrow flies unerring toward its mark—
A brilliant point of light piercing the dark.

IRON FLIGHT

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A mechanical meteor with purpose and with might.
Cutting through midnight's veil, its journey starting
Where city lights surrender to the depth of night.

I feel the gentle rocking, this cradle made of steel,
As strangers sleep around me, heads against the glass.
The world outside dissolves—too swift to seem quite real—
A smudged impressionist painting as we pass.

What ancient eyes once marveled at the speed of horse and cart?
What would they make of this arrow shot from modern bows?
These iron tracks that stitch the separate lands apart
And shrink the miles to moments as the landscape flows.

We are all passengers on journeys not our own,
Hurtling through darkness toward a dawn unknown,
Captive within this vessel's forward flight,
Drawing our own trajectories through the night.

Carving tunnels of light in midnight's shroud.
The passengers within, their journeys starting,
Sit silent as stars beneath night's cloud.

Metal serpent slithering on iron veins,
Whispering promises of elsewhere shores.
It carries dreams and sorrows, joys and pains,
As it thunders past fields and factory doors.

I press my forehead to the windowpane,
Watching shadows of towns quickly recede.
The rhythm rocks me as we cleave the plain,
A mechanical heart pumping at speed.

We are all arrows shot from different bows,
Momentarily aligned in this steel flight.
Where each soul ultimately lands or goes
Remains unwritten in the book of night.

VELOCITY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Splitting night's fabric with mechanical grace.
I count the heartbeats of departure, starting
The slow dissolution of time and space.

Steel wheels ignite brief sparks against the rails—
Ephemeral stars born and dying in an instant.
The countryside retreats, its detail pales,
As we accelerate, persistent, distant.

The coach rocks gently, lullaby of motion,
Cradling strangers in its metal embrace.
We drift between sleep and waking devotion
To landscapes flowing past like liquid lace.

Outside, the world contracts to streaks of light.
Inside, we float suspended between lives—
What we've left behind and what waits tonight—
As through earth's sleeping body, our arrow drives.

MIDNIGHT EXPRESS

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A needle threading through night's velvet cloak.
The passengers within, their dreams imparting
To windows streaked with rain and engine smoke.

We thunder forward on our iron course,
A constellation moving through the land.
Propelled by some invisible, ancient force
That humans harnessed with ingenious hand.

The clickety-clack becomes a meditation,
A mantra counting miles instead of breaths.
Between departure point and destination,
We exist suspended, neither life nor death.

The darkness presses heavy on the glass,
Reflecting faces ghosted by the night.
We speed toward dawn that's coming fast,
Transformed by journey into something bright.

TRANSIT

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Breathing smoke dragons into midnight air.
The wheels below us, rhythmic beats imparting,
Keep time with hearts of those who travel there.

We cut through sleeping towns and dreaming fields,
Momentary ghosts in others' static lives.
The carriage sways, to gravity half-yields,
As forward, ever forward, still it drives.

I watch the scattered lights of farms recede,
Small constellations anchored to the ground.
While we, untethered, gain relentless speed,
Leaving nothing but our hollow, fading sound.

In transit between what was and what will be,
Suspended in the liminality of night,
We arrow toward some new reality,
Carrying our stories toward the morning light.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,'

responses.text:

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A steel-tipped shaft released from time's relentless bow.
The countryside dissolves in blur, departing
As windows frame the night in amber glow.

Through sleeping villages and shadowed vales,
The rhythm of the rails becomes a song.

Of journeys ended, journeys just begun, journeys long.

The passengers, like dreams within this flight,
Float suspended between was and soon-to-be.
While stars above bear witness to our plight,
Celestial lanterns guiding all we see.

We pierce the darkness with our human will,
Modern pilgrims on ancient quests disguised.
The arrow flies, and though the world stands still,

ARROW OF PROGRESS

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Iron determination cutting night's thick veil.
A mechanical comet with fire in its heart starting
To inscribe its luminous, thundering trail.

It carries dreams and dreamers through the sleeping earth,
A vessel of possibility, of chance, of change.
Connecting distant stories, endings, points of birth,
As landscapes slip away, rearrange.

The passengers rock gently in its steady rush,
Some bound for joy, some fleeing from their pain.
In shared momentum, private thoughts they hush,
United briefly by the singing of the train.

We build these arrows not just to traverse the miles,
But to pierce the barriers of what we thought could be.
Through tunnels carved from doubt, across denial's trials,
The train shoots forward—unstoppable, wild, free.

NIGHT TRAJECTORY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Slicing midnight's canvas with precision keen.
A constellation of windows, yellow light imparting
Glimpses of lives in transit, moving yet unseen.

Steel wheels on steel rails sing their metallic hymn,
A rhythm ancient as commerce, new as speed.
The countryside retreats to memory's dim
Periphery, where distance and time are freed.

We passengers, reluctant archers of our fate,
Shot forward through the void between what was and is.
Neither here nor there, but in that strange estate
Of transition—that temporal precipice.

The darkness parts before our collective flight,
As tunnels, trees, and sleeping towns give way.
We are the arrow's feathers, guiding through the night,
Until we reach the target of a new-born day.

VELOCITY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A mechanical phantom with eyes of burning gold.
The night peels back from its relentless charting,
Revealing secrets that only travelers are told.

The carriage rocks with gentle undulation,
A cradle speeding toward some distant shore.
Each station passed, a brief illumination,
A comma in the journey, nothing more.

I press my face against the cool glass pane
And watch my breath create then cloud my view.
The world outside becomes a blurred refrain,
A smudged impression of what I once knew.

We are all arrows shot from different bows,
Momentarily aligned in parallel flight.
Toward destinations only morning shows,
Piercing together through the yielding night.

IRON TRAJECTORY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Cleaving shadows with its determined steel head.
The countryside sleeps unaware of our departing,
Fields and forests dream beneath a starlit spread.

The carriages link like thoughts in fluid motion,
Each window frames a story, each seat a temporary home.
We travel not just distance but emotion,
Collective solitude wherever we may roam.

The tracks ahead, twin ribbons stretching onward,
Guide our passage through the velvet hour.
The engine pulls us ceaselessly forward,
A testament to human ingenuity and power.

What ancient wanderer could have ever dreamed
Of hurtling through darkness with such grace and speed?
This arrow of progress, its purpose now redeemed,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,'

responses.text:
NIGHT JOURNEY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Piercing the velvet cloak of night with steel and light,
A mechanical comet with windows all aglow,
Carrying dreamers and wanderers through the void.

The rhythm of wheels becomes a heartbeat,
Each click-clack a second ticking on time's face,
While mountains sleep like giants under starlight,
And valleys cradle the silver tracks in their palms.

Passengers gaze at reflections in blackened glass,
Their faces ghostly overlaid on rushing landscapes,
Stories contained in metal carriages,
All bound to separate destinations yet sharing this flight.

The arrow flies relentless through shadows,
Drawing its line across the map of midnight,
Connecting dots of light—towns and villages
That flicker briefly then surrender to the darkness once more.

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
And we, its feathers, flutter in the slipstream of passing time.

STEEL TRAJECTORY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Slicing night's fabric with precision and grace,
A thundering whisper of human invention
Challenging shadows with defiant speed.

Iron wheels spinning tales of distance conquered,
Carrying souls between yesterday and tomorrow.
The carriages—vessels of hope and memory—
Glide over Earth's curved spine with determined purpose.

Windows frame fragments of sleeping landscapes,
Brief tableaux illuminated then swallowed again.
Inside, strangers share the liminal space
Between departures and arrivals, between was and will be.

The night folds around this mechanical serpent,
Its metal scales reflecting moonlight in flashes.
Tunnels swallow it whole then birth it anew,
As stars watch indifferent to our hurried journey.

We are all passengers on this arrow of progress,
Shot from the bow of necessity toward dawn's target,
Hurtling through darkness with blind faith
That light awaits beyond the curved horizon.

MIDNIGHT PASSAGE

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Cutting through midnight's dense tapestry,
A constellation of lit windows
Strung together by purpose and steel.

I press my forehead against cold glass,
Watching phantom landscapes dissolve—
Ghostly trees, abandoned platforms,
The brief geometry of distant homes.

The arrow vibrates with contained stories:
A woman clutching letters never sent,
A man rehearsing homecoming speeches,
Children dreaming in their mothers' arms.

We are all suspended between places,
Neither here nor there but somewhere in-between,
Caught in the momentum of departure
Yet not quite arrived at becoming.

The tracks beneath us sing metallic hymns,
A rhythmic lullaby for restless travelers.
The dark outside deepens, then relents
As dawn begins to thread the horizon with gold.

Like a long arrow released from night's bow,
We pierce the target of morning, transformed.

VELOCITY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A needle threading the fabric of night with iron and steam.
I count the seconds between telephone poles,
Measuring distance in heartbeats and breath.

Outside, the world smears into watercolor impressions—
Farmhouses, fields, and forests
All rendered in shades of midnight blue,
Touched briefly by our passing light.

The passengers around me have surrendered to dreams,
Heads nodding in unconscious rhythm with the track's percussion.
Only I remain awake to witness this arrow's flight,
This mechanical defiance of darkness and distance.

Somewhere ahead lies the target of our journey,
A station platform waiting to receive our momentum,
To transform our velocity into arrival,
Our motion into stillness once again.

But for now, we exist in perfect transit,
Neither beginning nor end but pure movement,
An equation of speed and direction,
A theorem of escape written in steel upon parallel lines.

IRON TRAJECTORY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Carving tunnels through time with its determined thrust.
The night spreads wide around us, a canvas of shadows
Painted with occasional lights from distant farmhouses.

I feel the vibration of wheels beneath my feet,
The steady pulse of machinery in motion,
As if I've placed my hand upon the chest
Of some great beast racing across the land.

Fellow travelers doze in their compartments,
Unaware of the poetry in our collective hurtling,
The beautiful physics of bodies in transit,
The miracle of distance being devoured by design.

We pass through small towns like a thought through mind—
Brief, illuminating, then gone—leaving only
The afterimage of our passing impressed
Upon the retina of local memory.

The conductor moves through carriages like a keeper of time,
Punching tickets that grant us passage through darkness.
And I wonder if the night itself feels our penetration,
This human arrow shot from the bow of necessity toward dawn.
