prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
# ABANDONED BY TEARS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They abandon me like fair-weather friends,
evaporating before witnessing my complete undoing.
Even my sorrow refuses loyalty.

How strange to be forsaken by your own grief,
to reach for evidence of pain
and find your cheeks mysteriously dry,
as if your body conspires against validation.

Perhaps tears know better than to linger
in the wasteland of perpetual anguish.
They flee toward happier vessels,
leaving me hollow, a desert of emotion.

I am the drought personified,
so parched that even sadness withholds its rain.
What remains when even the physical proof
of your breaking heart betrays you?

Only the echo of what might have been relief,
only the ghost of catharsis,
only the knowledge that I am so alone
even my tears refuse to keep me company.

# WATERLESS MOURNING

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They vanish like promises whispered at midnight,
leaving no evidence of their brief existence.
My grief, unwitnessed even by myself.

The salt tracks that should mark my face
refuse to manifest, as though my sorrow
is too insignificant for physical form.
Am I not worthy of visible pain?

I envy those whose anguish decorates their cheeks,
whose suffering leaves a glistening trail
for all the world to acknowledge.
Mine disappears before touching air.

Perhaps I've cried too often, depleted
the well from which tears are drawn.
Or perhaps my heart has learned
there's no relief in letting them fall.

So I stand in this strange drought of emotion,
feeling the storm but showing nothing,
betrayed by the very symbols of my distress,
abandoned by even the most intimate evidence of pain.

# DESERTION

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They flee from me like startled birds,
evaporating into the atmosphere,
leaving no witness to my collapse.

How curious that even liquid sorrow
rejects the gravity of my situation,
refusing to trail down my face
as if ashamed of its association with me.

I've become so hollow that sadness itself
finds no purchase on my being,
slipping away before anyone can notice
the depth of this internal drowning.

Perhaps I've grown too familiar with grief,
so accustomed to its weight
that my body no longer bothers
with the ceremony of visible pain.

So I stand here, dry-faced and breaking,
betrayed by the universal language of suffering,
left without even the small comfort
of knowing my anguish can be seen.

# FORSAKEN

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They betray me like everything else,
disappearing before they complete their journey,
leaving no evidence of their brief existence.

Is my sadness so insignificant
that even its physical manifestation
abandons me before reaching conclusion?
Am I unworthy of visible grief?

The world demands proof of suffering
before offering comfort or belief.
Yet here I stand, internally drowning,
externally bone-dry and unreadable.

Perhaps there is mercy in this desertion—
no red eyes to explain away,
no streaked makeup betraying weakness,
no salt stains marking vulnerability.

Still, I long for the validation
of witnessing my own pain made tangible,
for the small relief that comes
when emotion completes its intended arc.

# INVISIBLE CURRENTS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They vanish like morning mist touched by sun,
absorbed back into the atmosphere of my being,
leaving no trace of their momentary existence.

My grief flows in invisible currents,
a subterranean river that refuses surface tension,
denying me the simple dignity of witnessed pain.
Even my body conspires against my truth.

Perhaps this is evolution's cruel joke—
the development of sorrow that leaves no evidence,
pain that cannot be photographed or measured,
distress that society can comfortably ignore.

I place my fingers on dry cheeks,
searching for proof that I am still human,
still capable of the most basic expression
of the tempest raging within my chest.

In this drought of visible emotion,
I am left wondering if feelings unmanifested
are somehow less real, less deserving of comfort,
less worthy of the space they occupy in my heart.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
# Abandoned by Grief

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side,
They abandon me like fairweather friends,
Slipping away down cheeks carved by time,
Leaving only salt and hollow ends.

Even my sorrow refuses to linger,
Dissipating into the callous air,
I reach for the wet proof of my anguish
But my fingers grasp only at what isn't there.

How lonely to be forsaken by your own pain,
When the physical evidence of hurt takes flight,
Leaving you dry in a desert of emotion,
With nothing but memory to prove the night.

Perhaps there is mercy in their swift departure,
These liquid children of my despair,
But I wish just once they'd stay to witness
The aftermath they leave in disrepair.

# Ephemeral Companions

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side,
They race down pathways of skin, eager to depart,
As if my sorrow is too heavy a burden
Even for the manifestations of my broken heart.

They glisten momentarily, these fragile diamonds,
Then vanish into collar, floor, or waiting hand,
Leaving no evidence of their brief existence,
No testament to pain you might understand.

What loyalty can I expect from water and salt,
When even my own body conspires against me?
These tears—born of my anguish—betraying their creator,
Disappearing like whispered secrets lost at sea.

Perhaps I should learn from their hasty retreat,
To carry my grief more lightly, to let it flow
Through me and beyond me, not clinging to pain,
But allowing it passage, then letting it go.

# Desertion

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side,
They flee like cowards from a losing war,
Abandoning the battlefield of my face
To evaporate into nothingness, and nothing more.

Each droplet—a traitor to my suffering—
Refuses to bear witness to this pain.
They fall away, these liquid deserters,
Leaving me to carry my burden again.

How strange to feel betrayed by your own grief,
When the physical proof of sorrow won't remain,
As if the universe denies you even this small comfort:
The validation of your visible pain.

Perhaps there's wisdom in their swift departure,
A lesson wrapped in salty dissolution:
Nothing lasts—not joy, not pain, not tears—
Everything flows toward its own conclusion.

# Transient Witnesses

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side,
They rush to escape the prison of my eyes,
As if ashamed to be born from such sorrow,
They hurry to vanish under gravity's disguise.

What faithless companions these droplets prove,
Formed in the crucible of my despair,
Yet unwilling to stand as testimony
To the ache that summoned them to air.

I watch them disappear into fabric and skin,
Leaving damp ghosts that quickly fade,
No evidence remains of their brief existence,
No proof of the price my heart has paid.

Perhaps in their desertion lies a message:
That grief itself was never meant to stay,
That even the wettest sorrow must dry,
As time and wind carry the pain away.

# Liquid Betrayal

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side,
They race to escape the confines of my face,
Ambitious little traitors with places to be,
Leaving behind no mark, no sign, no trace.

How cruel this liquid betrayal feels,
When even the physical form of grief
Refuses to linger as testament
To the depth of pain beyond belief.

They slip between fingers that try to catch them,
These elusive children of my despair,
Born from the ocean of my suffering
Yet unwilling their creator's fate to share.

Perhaps I should envy their swift departure,
Their freedom to dissolve and disappear,
While I remain, anchored to this moment,
Unable to escape what brought them here.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
# Abandoned by Tears

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side,
They abandon me like fair-weather friends,
Racing down my cheeks in hasty descent,
Eager to escape the hollow vessel I've become.

Even my sorrow refuses my company,
Evaporating into the callous air,
Leaving no evidence of my breaking heart,
No witnesses to this silent unraveling.

How lonely to be forsaken by your own grief,
When the physical manifestation of pain
Slips through fingers desperate for something to hold.

I am a desert now, parched and barren,
My sadness a phantom that visits briefly,
Then disappears without leaving footprints
In the wasteland of what once was whole.

# Ephemeral Mourning

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They race down pathways of forgotten smiles,
Disappearing into the fabric of my clothes,
Becoming nothing but damp memories.

What loyalty can I expect from liquid sorrow
When even the salt of my own making
Refuses to linger in solidarity?

Gravity pulls them away from me,
As if the earth itself is more deserving
Of these crystalline confessions.

Perhaps there is wisdom in their departure—
A lesson in the temporary nature of pain,
How nothing, not even grief, remains constant.

So I watch them go, these fleeting companions,
And wonder if someday I too might learn
The art of not staying where I am not meant to remain,
Of flowing onward when the moment calls for release.

# Desertion

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They betray me with their swift descent,
Racing away as if ashamed of their source,
Leaving trails of abandonment across my skin.

How curious that the physical form of grief
Should be so eager to depart its creator,
As if my sadness is too heavy to bear
Even for the very embodiment of sorrow.

Perhaps they know something I have yet to learn—
That clinging to pain only deepens its roots,
That freedom comes in the letting go.

Still, I wish for once they would linger,
Validate the ache that birthed them,
Witness the trembling of my hands,
The quivering of my lips as I whisper
To empty rooms and hollow echoes.

But they continue their exodus,
Teaching me the cruel art of release.

# Transient Companions

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They fall like rain from clouds of my despair,
Rejecting the landscape of my face,
Hurrying to somewhere beyond my reach.

Is there nothing in this world that remains?
Not even the water from my own eyes
Will pledge allegiance to my suffering.

They travel downward, these droplets of pain,
Obedient to laws of nature, not emotion,
Unconcerned with the turmoil that birthed them.

Perhaps I should learn from their journey—
How they emerge from darkness into light,
How they transform from internal anguish
To external release, catching sunlight
As they fall, momentarily beautiful
In their brief existence between worlds.

Maybe there is freedom in this abandonment,
In learning that even sorrow must eventually
Find its way back to the earth.

# Liquid Betrayal

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They rush away like disloyal soldiers,
Deserting the battlefield of my face
When the war within me rages strongest.

Each droplet born from the well of my pain
Seeks immediate escape, urgent departure,
As if my sorrow is contagious,
Something from which even its manifestations flee.

I watch them vanish into cloth, into air,
Leaving nothing but salt trails and memories,
Ghosts of evidence that I felt anything at all.

In their absence, I wonder:
Am I so unbearable that even parts of me
Cannot stand to remain?

Yet perhaps in their journey away,
They carry burdens I was never meant to hold,
Teaching me that release, not retention,
Is how we survive the storms that rage within.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
Abandoned Waters

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They abandon me like everything else,
Slipping down my cheeks in silent betrayal,
Making their escape to somewhere unknown.

Even my sorrow won't remain faithful,
Even my pain refuses my company.
The salt of my anguish evaporates,
Leaving nothing but dry trails of memory.

How lonely it is to lose even your sadness,
To watch it drip away without permission.
My grief, my only constant companion,
Now fleeting like morning dew under harsh sun.

I reach for the wetness as proof I still feel,
But my fingertips touch only the ghost of emotion.
Even the witnesses to my breaking heart
Desert me before their testimony is complete.

Desertion

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They race down my face in hurried escape,
As if ashamed of their origin,
As if my cheeks were burning their delicate forms.

Even liquid sorrow rejects my company,
Seeks freedom from the prison of my grief.
What loyalty can I expect from others
When my own sadness refuses to linger?

The droplets merge with dust and disappear,
Leaving no evidence of their brief existence.
My pain—visible for just a moment—
Then gone, like whispers in a hurricane.

I am abandoned by my own emotion,
Betrayed by the physical proof of my heart breaking.
Left alone in the desert of my despair,
Too dry now even for the comfort of weeping.

Ephemeral Grief

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They race toward earth with gravitational certainty,
Denying me ownership of my own sorrow,
Refusing to remain as evidence of my pain.

How cruel that even sadness is temporary,
That the water from my soul evaporates so quickly.
I cannot hold onto anything—not joy, not grief—
All slips between fingers spread wide with longing.

The world drinks my tears without permission,
Absorbs them into its endless thirst for suffering.
I am left with nothing but salt-stained cheeks
And the memory of wetness already fading.

Perhaps there is mercy in this abandonment,
In the refusal of pain to make a permanent home.
Yet I find myself reaching for those departed drops,
Wishing they would linger just a moment longer.

Liquid Betrayal

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They flee from me like startled birds,
Tracing paths of escape down my hollow cheeks,
Dissolved into the atmosphere before I can catch them.

Even my body betrays my need to grieve,
Producing evidence that vanishes too quickly.
I am left with nothing tangible to show,
For the earthquake rumbling through my chest.

How strange to miss something so small,
To yearn for the company of salt water,
To feel abandoned by droplets of myself,
Scattered and lost to the thirsty air.

Perhaps I should learn from these nomadic tears,
That nothing was meant to stay forever.
Not love, not pain, not even the proof of suffering—
All things must journey away from their source.

Transient Witnesses

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They depart in silent procession,
My only witnesses choosing exile
Rather than bearing testimony to my undoing.

Each droplet carries a fragment of my story
Only to surrender it to thirsty earth or hungry air.
My sadness becomes a vanishing act,
A magic trick where evidence disappears.

I press my fingers to my cheeks,
Searching for proof that I am still capable of feeling.
But the skin is already dry, as if denying
That moments ago it was flooded with grief.

Perhaps there is wisdom in their departure—
These liquid messengers teaching me
That even sorrow must eventually transform,
That nothing, not even our pain, will forever remain.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
# Abandoned by My Own Sorrow

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They abandon me like fair-weather friends,
Rolling down my hollow cheeks
To vanish into the thirsty earth below.

Even my grief refuses loyalty,
Escaping in translucent droplets,
Leaving nothing but salt-stained trails
And the echo of their departure.

How strange to be forsaken
By the very evidence of my pain—
These liquid witnesses born of my anguish
Rushing away as if ashamed of their maker.

I reach to catch them, to hold them close,
As proof that what I feel is real,
But they slip between trembling fingers,
Too quick, too eager to be gone.

So I stand empty, abandoned twice:
Once by what broke me,
And once by the tears that should have stayed
To validate the breaking.

# Desertion

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They race down pathways carved by time,
Eager to escape the prison of my eyes,
Traitors to the sorrow that birthed them.

What loyalty can I expect from water
When even my own heart betrays me daily?
These droplets—children of my pain—
Depart without goodbye or backward glance.

Gravity pulls them earthward,
As something heavier pulls me down.
Yet they are free to evaporate, transform,
While I remain tethered to this aching.

Perhaps I envy their swift departure,
Their refusal to linger in misery.
They know better than to dwell
In the shadow-lands of what cannot be changed.

So let them go, these fleeting witnesses.
I'll forge my solitude from stronger stuff
Than salt and water, fragile as memory—
A fortress built from abandoned tears.

# Liquid Betrayal

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They flee like cowards from a losing battle,
Sliding down the curve of my face
To disappear into nothingness.

Even my sorrow lacks conviction,
Diluting itself in hasty retreat.
What faithless companions these droplets,
Born of my pain yet quick to abandon.

Is there nothing in this world
That remains when needed most?
Even these salt-water confessions
Rush to distance themselves from their source.

I watch them fall, these liquid traitors,
Splashing onto cold floors and colder hands.
Each one carries a fragment of my story
Yet none will stay to tell it.

So I am left with dry cheeks
And a paradox of emptiness and fullness—
Overflowing with grief that produces
Evidences of pain too disloyal to linger.

# The Ephemeral Mourners

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They are born between heartbeats,
Glistening momentarily like morning dew
Before surrendering to gravity's inevitable pull.

How curious that these liquid pieces of myself
Should be so eager to depart,
As if they've learned some secret wisdom
About the futility of dwelling in sorrow.

Perhaps they understand what I cannot—
That clinging serves no purpose,
That even grief must eventually release
Its tight-fisted grip on the present moment.

Still, I wish they'd linger longer,
These tangible proofs of feeling,
Instead of racing toward oblivion
Leaving nothing but phantom trails on skin.

In their hasty departure I find a lesson:
Nothing stays—not joy, not pain, not tears.
Even the witnesses to our deepest anguish
Must eventually continue their journey without us.

# Forsaken Waters

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They cascade from reluctant eyes,
Dancing away on currents of air,
Refusing the comfort of shared solitude.

What strange companions, these droplets
That spring from the well of my despair
Only to forsake their creator,
Leaving no evidence of their brief existence.

I wonder where they journey to,
These fragments of liquid emotion.
Do they merge with rain and rivers,
Diluting themselves in larger sorrows?

Perhaps they are wiser than I,
Knowing that lingering serves no purpose,
That even grief must eventually transform
Or evaporate into the ether of memory.

So I stand alone with my dry aftermath,
Abandoned by the very symbols of my pain,
Learning slowly that nothing remains constant—
Not even the tears we shed for constancy.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
ABANDONED TEARS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side,
They abandon me like friends who couldn't abide
The weight of my sorrow, the depth of my pain,
Slipping away like whispers in the rain.

Even my grief refuses to remain,
Droplets escaping down paths they've stained,
Leaving salt tracks—evidence they were here—
But gone too quickly, these disloyal tears.

What loyalty can I expect from this world
When even my own sadness is unfurled
And scattered like ashes upon the breeze?
My emotion—fleeting, quick to appease

The gravity that pulls all things away from me.
I am a planet losing moons to the sea
Of endless space, of emptiness profound.
My tears, like everything else, won't stay around.

EPHEMERAL GRIEF

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They race down my cheeks in a hurried slide,
Eager to leave me, quick to depart,
As if embarrassed by my breaking heart.

How strange that something born of my pain
Would rush to dissolve, refusing to remain.
Even expressions of my deepest grief
Seek escape routes, desperate for relief.

Perhaps they know what I've yet to learn:
That clinging to sorrow makes the soul burn.
They fall and vanish, returning to air,
Teaching by example not to linger in despair.

So I'll watch them go, these liquid betrayers,
These crystalline drops, my emotion's layers.
And maybe someday, when healing begins,
I'll thank these tears for not settling in.

DESERTION

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They desert me like soldiers fleeing a lost fight,
Slipping away down the curve of my face,
Leaving no comfort, no lingering trace.

Even my sorrow refuses companionship,
As droplets form then quickly lose their grip.
Is nothing sacred? Not even pain?
Not even grief willing to remain?

I am abandoned by my own expression,
Left hollow in the wake of this confession.
The universe teaches its cruelest lesson:
Even what comes from within will not listen.

So I stand empty, watching them fall,
These traitors of emotion, one and all.
Perhaps there's wisdom in their hasty retreat—
Nothing stays forever, not even defeat.

TRANSIENT COMPANIONS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side,
They journey downward, on gravity's ride.
Born from my anguish, children of pain,
Yet so quick to leave me, again and again.

We share but moments, these drops and I,
A brief connection before they say goodbye.
What lesson hides in their urgent departure?
What wisdom lies in this watery rupture?

Perhaps they whisper: nothing remains,
Not joy, not sorrow, not losses or gains.
Even the grief that feels carved in stone
Will someday dissolve, leaving me alone.

Or maybe they're scouts sent to explore
The world beyond my trembling shore.
Reporting back to the ocean inside:
There's life beyond the tears we've cried.

FAITHLESS WATERS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They betray me with each blink, ready to glide
Away from their source, their very creation,
As if my cheeks were merely a temporary station.

How cruel this metaphor for all I've known—
Even parts of me refuse to call me home.
They rush toward earth with determined haste,
Leaving behind only a salty taste.

What is it about me that nothing remains?
Not love, not friendship, not even my pains.
Am I a vessel designed just to release?
A temporary harbor granting no peace?

Perhaps there's freedom in this liquid flight,
In watching attachments dissolve in plain sight.
For if my own tears won't claim allegiance,
Perhaps I too might learn such resilience.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I Hunted Words Of Skill'

responses.text:
I Hunted Words Of Skill

With bow of thought and arrows sharp,
I stalked through forests of the mind,
Where syllables like creatures dart
Between the shadows, hard to find.

I hunted words of skill and grace,
Those elusive, perfect turns of phrase,
That capture life in their embrace
And set the dormant soul ablaze.

Some words fled swift as startled deer,
While others lurked in thickets deep,
I tracked them through the hemispheres
Of consciousness and restless sleep.

My quiver filled with metaphors,
With similes and sounds that sing,
I claimed the treasures, rich and pure,
That only patient hunters bring.

Now here they lie upon the page,
These hard-won trophies of my quest,
A testament to human rage
For beauty captured, then expressed.

I Hunted Words Of Skill

Through lexicon's vast wilderness I tread,
A hunter tracking prints of ancient thought.
My fingers, calloused scribes, have often bled
In pursuit of the phrases wisdom wrought.

I stalked the shadows where rare verbs reclined,
And crouched in wait for adjectives to bloom.
The noun, a creature cautious and refined,
Lured me through dictionary's dusty room.

I hunted words of skill with patient heart,
Not for mere sport but sustenance of soul.
Each captured term became a vital part
Of something greater than its simple whole.

Sometimes the prey escaped my earnest grasp,
Ideas too fleet to pin upon the page.
Yet still I hunt as daylight hours pass,
Collecting language's precious heritage.

For in this quest I've found my truest self—
A gatherer of sounds that spark and shine,
More valuable than any worldly wealth:
These words of skill I've hunted to make mine.

I Hunted Words Of Skill

I hunted words of skill through midnight oil,
Trapped them between the lines of empty sheets.
They struggled, wild and free, against my toil,
Resisting capture in their swift retreats.

Some words were predators, with teeth and claw,
That tore at certainties I held too dear.
Others, like wounded birds, inspired awe—
Their fragile beauty making meaning clear.

I tracked them through the underbrush of thought,
Across the plains of doubt, through valleys deep.
The cleverest ones were hardest to be caught;
They visited my dreams in troubled sleep.

My traps were questions baited with desire,
My snares were woven from experience.
I chased them to exhaustion, never tire,
Until they yielded their intelligence.

Now mounted on this page, my trophy wall,
These words of skill stare back with knowing eyes.
They're captive, yes, but somehow, after all,
I am the one transformed by their surprise.

I Hunted Words Of Skill

I hunted words of skill across vast plains
Of blank white pages, trackless as new snow.
Armed with a pen—my spear—I sought to gain
The perfect phrase to make my meaning glow.

The metaphor, a creature swift and shy,
Evaded me through forests of cliché.
While similes, like stars in distant sky,
Shone tantalizingly, then slipped away.

I followed trails of rhythm through the night,
Where footprints of the masters marked the ground.
Sometimes in darkness came a flash of light—
A perfect word that turned my thoughts around.

I hunted through the thickets of my mind,
Where memories and dreams entangled grew.
Some days returned with nothing I could find,
While others yielded treasures, rich and true.

This hunt continues as the seasons change,
A lifelong quest for language's bright gems.
Through syntax's familiar, yet strange,
Wild territories, seeking diadems

Of thought, distilled to essence, pure and clear—
The words of skill I hunted brought me here.

I Hunted Words Of Skill

I hunted words of skill in darkness deep,
Where language hides its most elusive prey.
Through dictionaries vast I chose to creep,
Stalking the perfect terms that fled away.

With net of patience woven fine and strong,
I waited for the rhythm's subtle beat.
For hours stretched to days, then seasons long,
I gathered sounds both bitter and sweet.

The metaphor—a creature quick and sly—
Required cunning traps of thought to snare.
While assonance like birds across the sky
Flew patterns I would follow if I dare.

I hunted words of skill not for mere sport,
But sustenance to feed a hungry soul.
Each syllable a castle, phrase a fort
Where meaning's treasures waited to be stole.

And when my hunt proved fruitful, how I'd smile
To string these trophies on the line of verse,
Knowing the chase had been, all the while,
The greater prize than what filled language's purse.

For in this hunt I found myself anew—
A craftsman shaped by what I sought to do.

I Hunted Words Of Skill

Through forests of thought I stalked my prey,
Quill poised like an arrow, ready to slay
The perfect phrase hiding in shadow and light,
Elusive metaphors taking sudden flight.

I hunted words of skill in ancient tomes,
In whispered secrets and forgotten poems,
Tracking footprints of meaning across the page,
Gathering wisdom from every sage.

Sometimes they came easy, falling like rain,
Other times they caused such exquisite pain,
As I waited in silence, patient and still,
For that perfect moment, that writer's thrill.

My trophy wall lined with captured verse,
Some blessing, some blessing, some curse,
Each one hard-won through relentless pursuit,
Prized possessions, my linguistic loot.

Still I hunt, dawn till dusk, day after day,
For words of skill will never cease to prey
Upon my mind, my heart, my very soul,
This endless chase that makes me whole.

I Hunted Words Of Skill

With nets woven from desperate need,
I hunted words of skill across barren pages.
They darted like silver fish between thoughts,
Leaving only ripples where meaning should be.

I stalked them through dictionaries,
Trapped them in the corners of conversations,
Lured them with silence and patience,
Only to watch them dissolve at my touch.

Some days the words were plentiful,
Falling like autumn leaves into my waiting hands.
Other days brought drought to my tongue,
And thirst to my ink-stained fingers.

I hunted words of skill,
Not knowing they were hunting me as well,
Circling my consciousness like wolves,
Waiting for weakness, for surrender.

In the end, we reached an understanding,
The words and I, reluctant partners
In this eternal dance of creation.
I ceased to hunt, and learned instead to listen.

Now they come unbidden, these words of skill,
No longer prey, but companions on the journey.

I Hunted Words Of Skill

With bow of thought and arrows of desire,
I hunted words of skill through tangled briars.
Through misty vales of doubt I tracked their trail,
Where lesser hunters would surrender, fail.

Each syllable a prize, each phrase a beast
That roamed the wild lands of mind released.
Some gentle creatures came with willing grace,
While others led me on a breathless chase.

The rarest words, they hid in shadowed caves,
Beneath the surface of convention's waves.
I dove for them with lungs about to burst,
To quench my never-ending language thirst.

Some nights returned with empty hands, no kill,
Yet dawn would find me hunting, stubborn still.
For in this chase, the hunt itself sustains
More than the trophies that one finally gains.

I've built a home from all these words I've caught,
A shelter fashioned from my captured thought.
Yet still I hunt, for skill has no finality,
Just endless paths through verbal reality.

I Hunted Words Of Skill

I hunted words of skill across paper plains,
Stalking through forests of forgotten lore,
Tracking the footprints of ancient refrains,
Searching for treasures that lived before.

My quiver filled with questions sharp and true,
My mind the bow that sent them flying fast,
Each captured phrase a victory anew,
A bridge connecting future with the past.

Some words came willingly into my snare,
Others required patience, stealth, and guile.
The rarest ones, so precious and so rare,
Often eluded me for quite a while.

In moonlit libraries, I laid my traps,
Baited with curiosity and need.
I studied linguistic maps and gaps,
Planting in barren ground a fertile seed.

The hunt continues as the seasons change,
For words, like wild creatures, never cease
To roam the vast expanse of language range,
Their capture bringing both triumph and peace.

I hunted words of skill, and in the end,
Discovered they were hunting me as well.

I Hunted Words Of Skill

Through valleys deep and mountains tall,
I hunted words of skill, I hunted all.
With net and trap and clever snare,
I sought the phrases hiding there.

Beneath the rocks of common speech,
Beyond the tides of easy reach,
The perfect words, they skittered fast,
Elusive shadows darting past.

Some nights I'd catch a glimmer bright,
A metaphor that shone with light,
Or simile with graceful form,
A verbal creature, wild, untamed.

I tracked them through the forest dense,
Of consciousness and experience,
Leaving behind the paths well-worn,
Where clichés rest, tired and forlorn.

My quiver filled with adjectives,
My pockets stuffed with narratives,
Yet still I hunt with restless heart,
This endless quest, this writer's art.

For when I think my hunt complete,
New words emerge on nimble feet,
And I, devoted to my skill,
Must hunt again, and always will.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

responses.text:
She lies alone upon her bed,
A tapestry of thoughts inside her head.
Memories dance like shadows on the wall,
Whispering stories of summer and fall.

The moonlight paints her room in silver hue,
Illuminating dreams both old and new.
Her fingers trace the empty space beside,
Where once a love did peacefully abide.

The clock ticks on in steady, solemn beat,
A rhythm to which her heart cannot compete.
For in the silence of the midnight hour,
Loneliness blooms like a forgotten flower.

Yet in this solitude she finds her strength,
A quiet power that stretches at full length.
For she who lies alone upon her bed
Carries universes within her head.

She lies alone upon her bed
With constellations spinning in her head.
The ceiling's vast expanse becomes the sky
Where unspoken wishes learn to fly.

The sheets, like waves upon a restless sea,
Bear witness to what she used to be.
A photograph face-down on wooden stands,
A ring no longer gracing gentle hands.

The house breathes quiet in these midnight hours,
As she counts seconds that devour
The remnants of a day now put to rest,
A bird returned too early to its nest.

In solitude, her spirit starts to mend
The broken pieces that refused to bend.
She lies alone, but finds within this space
A freedom that no sorrow can erase.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A kingdom made of cotton and of thread.
The guardian of secrets never told,
Of stories both the timid and the bold.

The window frames the night in darkened glass,
Reflecting how the hours slowly pass.
Her breath, a gentle rhythm in the dark,
Carries dreams that glimmer like a spark.

The world outside continues on its way,
Unaware of thoughts that hold their sway
Within the mind of one who lies awake,
Contemplating choices she might make.

In solitude there's power to be found,
In silence, truths profound and sound.
She lies alone, yet never truly so—
For in her mind, entire worlds still grow.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A fortress built of quilts around her spread.
The battle of the day has taken toll,
Leaving weary both her heart and soul.

The ceiling fan spins stories overhead,
Of lives unlived and words she never said.
Her eyes trace cracks along the aging paint,
Geographies of time, both bold and faint.

Beside her rests a book with dog-eared page,
A temporary escape from life's own stage.
Her phone lies dark, no messages appear
To break the silence ringing in her ear.

Yet in this moment of complete repose,
A strength within her steadily grows.
For she who rests alone upon this night
Prepares again for morning's coming light.

She lies alone upon her bed,
With whispers of the past inside her head.
The shadows dance across the weathered wall,
Like memories that refuse to fall.

Her fingers clutch the letter, creased and worn,
Its edges softened, its message torn
Between what could have been and what remains—
A love that flourished, then dissolved like rain.

The distant sound of traffic ebbs and flows,
A city's lullaby that comes and goes.
While she remains, a constant in this room,
A flower waiting patiently to bloom.

For solitude is not the same as lone,
And silence not the absence of a tone.
She lies alone, yet carries in her breast
A universe of dreams that cannot rest.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

responses.text:
She lies alone upon her bed,
Shadows dancing on the wall,
Memories like ghosts in her head,
Whispering of times beyond recall.

The moonlight filters through the blinds,
Casting silver on her face,
As she sifts through tangled minds,
Searching for a safer place.

The clock ticks on in steady beat,
Marking time that will not wait,
While her heart, in slow retreat,
Wonders what might be its fate.

She reaches for the empty space,
Where once a lover's hand would rest,
Remembering a warm embrace,
That once had made her feel so blessed.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A universe contained within,
Dreams and fears and words unsaid,
Waiting for the dawn to begin.

She lies alone upon her bed
Like a fallen autumn leaf,
Carried by winds that have fled,
Leaving nothing but silent grief.

The ceiling stares back, blank and white,
A canvas for her wandering mind,
As hours stretch into endless night,
And sleep remains hard to find.

Her fingers trace invisible lines
Across the empty sheets beside,
Where only phantom warmth reclines,
And memories refuse to hide.

The world outside continues on,
Unaware of her quiet pain,
As stars fade with approaching dawn,
Another day to bear again.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A warrior in her private war,
Fighting battles in her head,
Until she can't fight anymore.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A constellation of dreams unfurled,
Not in sorrow or in dread,
But mapping her internal world.

The solitude, a chosen friend,
Embraced like a familiar song,
In this space where thoughts transcend,
She finds where she might belong.

Books scattered like faithful guards,
Protecting her imaginings,
As her mind leaps forward, disregards
The limits of ordinary things.

The universe expands within
The chamber of her quiet room,
Where galaxies of thought begin
And possibilities bloom.

She lies alone upon her bed,
Not lonely, but complete, instead,
A universe unto herself,
Needing no one else.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A shipwreck on an ocean shore,
With tides of thought that surge and spread
Across the chambers of her core.

The ceiling fan spins lazy rounds,
Hypnotic in its gentle sway,
A metronome to all the sounds
That fill the closing of the day.

Her body still, her mind in flight,
Traversing landscapes far and wide,
A traveler in the dead of night
With no companion at her side.

The walls that hold her cannot keep
The vastness of her soul contained,
As through dimensions dark and deep
Her spirit wanders, unchained.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A universe in human form,
Neither living, neither dead,
But somewhere in the space between storms.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A painting framed by rumpled sheets,
With auburn hair like flames outspread,
And breath that softly falls and beats.

The world has turned its back today,
Left her to wrestle with her thoughts,
As sunlight makes its final play,
Across the battlefields she's fought.

Her fingers clutch a faded note,
The last remains of promises,
Words that someone somewhere wrote,
Now ghosts of former tenderness.

Yet in this solitude she finds
A strength that company conceals,
The quiet power that unwinds
When one confronts what time reveals.

She lies alone upon her bed,
But loneliness is not her fate,
For in herself, when all is said,
She finds the peace for which others wait.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

responses.text:
She lies alone upon her bed,
A fortress built of silk and thread,
Where shadows dance across the wall,
And memories rise, then gently fall.

The moonlight spills across her face,
Illuminating empty space,
Where once his body used to rest,
A hollow now within her chest.

The clock ticks forward, never back,
Each moment stretching, fading black,
As she recalls what used to be,
Before the storm swept out to sea.

Her fingers trace the vacant sheets,
Where phantom warmth no longer meets
The chill that settles in her bones,
As night consumes what daylight loans.

She lies alone upon her bed,
With unsaid words inside her head,
And waits for sleep to claim her soul,
To make her broken spirit whole.

She lies alone upon her bed
Thoughts spiraling in her head
Like autumn leaves in restless wind
Of paths not taken, words unsaid.

The ceiling's blank canvas above
Bears witness to her silent tears
As moonbeams filter through the blinds
Illuminating distant years.

The universe expands within
Her chest that rises, falls, and sighs
A cosmos born of flesh and bone
Where galaxies of dreams arise.

Her solitude, a sacred space
Where truth can finally breathe free
No masks to wear, no roles to play
Just essence of what used to be.

She lies alone upon her bed
A universe contained in skin
The vastness of her soul unfolds
As night's dark journey can begin.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A constellation of regrets
Spread across her weary frame
Like stars that haven't risen yet.

The ceiling fan spins histories,
Whirring tales of might-have-beens,
Circling like vultures over
The carcass of abandoned dreams.

Outside, the city never sleeps,
Its pulse a mockery of rest,
Sirens wailing lullabies
To soothe her unquiet breast.

Her phone glows blue beside her hand,
A portal to a different life,
Where smiles are currency and love
Is measured in electronic strife.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A shipwreck on a cotton sea,
Waiting for the tide of dawn
To carry her to where she's free.

She lies alone upon her bed,
The world outside has gone to rest.
While cities sleep and stars keep watch,
A war rages within her chest.

The quilt – a shield against the cold,
Cannot protect from memories old.
They pierce like needles through the dark,
As embers of what life once sparked.

The photograph upon the stand
Still holds the touch of his warm hand.
Now frozen smiles and captured light
Are all that keep her through the night.

The ceiling bears her whispered prayers,
The walls contain her silent cries.
The mirror knows her changing face,
The window frames her restless eyes.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A universe of one instead
Of two who once shared cosmic dreams,
Now shattered by life's jagged seams.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A garden of bones and flesh,
Cultivating dreams like wildflowers
In the fertile soil of night.

The clock's mechanical heartbeat
Echoes against hollow walls,
Measuring moments between breaths,
Between being and nothingness.

Her fingers—ten pale explorers—
Map territories of cotton sheets,
Searching for landmarks of comfort
In this landscape of solitude.

The ceiling holds her gaze captive,
A blank canvas for projections
Of parallel lives unlived,
Of doorways never opened.

She lies alone upon her bed,
Neither prisoner nor free,
Suspended in the amber of twilight,
Where yesterday and tomorrow meet.

In this liminal space of dusk,
She becomes both vessel and ocean,
Containing multitudes of silence
As the night unfolds around her.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

responses.text:
She lies alone upon her bed,
A fortress made of quilts and dreams,
Where shadows dance across the wall,
And silence isn't what it seems.

Her thoughts, like birds with restless wings,
Flutter against her windowpane,
Seeking escape from memory's cage,
Yet finding only glass and rain.

The clock ticks forward, merciless,
Each second drops like heavy stones,
Into the well of sleepless nights,
Where echoes turn to weary moans.

Beneath her pillow, letters rest,
The ink now faded, words still clear,
A history written by their hands,
Before his presence disappeared.

She lies alone upon her bed,
But solitude's a crowded space,
Where ghosts of what could never be,
Still haunt the curves of her embrace.

She lies alone upon her bed
Of wilted roses, thorns and rue,
The ceiling fan spins tales above
Of summers lost and skies once blue.

The window frames a crescent moon,
A sliver of reflected light,
That curves like questions never asked
Across the canvas of the night.

Her fingers trace invisible maps
Across the sheets of vacant space,
Where once his body carved a home,
Now only wrinkles leave their trace.

The walls inhale her whispered prayers,
Exhale the dust of broken vows,
As midnight stretches endless arms
Around her solitary boughs.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A shipwrecked sailor on dry land,
Adrift in oceans made of time,
With shores too distant to command.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A constellation of one star,
The universe collapsed within
The boundaries of who we are.

The ceiling watches, pale and blank,
A canvas for her restless mind,
Where painted scenes of yesterday
With tomorrow's dreams entwined.

Her breath, a gentle tide that pulls
Against the shoreline of her chest,
A rhythm ancient as the moon,
Yet fragile as a robin's nest.

Outside, the city never sleeps,
Its pulse a counterpoint to hers,
A symphony of separate lives,
Each note distinct, yet still occurs

Within the greater melody
Of human hearts that beat alone.
She lies there, both apart and part
Of something larger than her own.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A prisoner of cotton sheets,
While copper sunlight filters through
The curtains' gauzy, thin deceits.

Her body forms a question mark
Against the mattress' firm reply,
As dust motes dance in golden beams,
Like memories that won't comply.

The bookshelf holds her paper friends,
Their spines aligned in colorful rows,
Each one a world she's traveled through
While anchored to her own repose.

She counts the cracks along the wall,
A roadmap to some nowhere place,
As clocks tick-tock their stern rebuke
Against her languid, measured pace.

She lies alone upon her bed,
But solitude's not emptiness—
It's space where selfhood can expand
Beyond what others might express.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A ship adrift on linen seas,
The captain of a voyage stalled,
With no wind caught within her sails.

The ceiling's vast and empty sky
Stares back with indifferent gaze,
As hours drip like morphine drops
Through veins of long forgotten days.

Her phone lies silent by her side,
A black hole where words disappear,
Swallowed by the void between
What's spoken and what others hear.

The walls breathe in her solitude,
Expand and contract with her sighs,
As photographs in wooden frames
Hold moments frozen in their eyes.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A universe contained in skin,
The stars and planets of her thoughts
Collide with what might have been.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

responses.text:
She lies alone upon her bed,
A canvas of thoughts inside her head.

Illuminating battles fought within.

Silent tears trace paths well known,
On pillows where her dreams have flown.
Memories dance like shadows cast,
Echoes of a vibrant past.

Fingers clutch at empty space,
Where once she felt a warm embrace.
The clock ticks on with steady beat,
A rhythm to her heart's defeat.

Yet in this solitude so deep,
She plants new seeds of hope to reap.
For morning light will surely break,
And with it, strength for her to take.

She lies alone upon her bed,
But journeys far inside her head.

She lies alone upon her bed
With whispers of the day unsaid
The ceiling stares in mute reply
As shadows dance and multiply

The weight of silence fills the room
A heavy cloak, a gentle tomb
Where thoughts unfold like origami
Complex designs of joy and agony

Her breath creates a rhythm soft
A metronome that carries oft
The fragments of what might have been
Between the spaces in-between

The sheets become an ocean vast
Where she is drifting, unmoored, cast
Adrift upon the night's dark tide
With only memories as guide

She lies alone upon her bed
But worlds collide inside her head

She lies alone upon her bed,
A constellation of regrets above her head.
The room breathes slowly with her sighs,
As twilight paints the evening skies.

The empty space beside her form
Remains unoccupied but warm
With phantom touches, whispered names,
And love that flickers like small flames.

The walls have heard her secrets spilled,
The floor has felt her footsteps stilled.
The mirror watched her courage grow
Through seasons high and seasons low.

In solitude she finds her strength,
A quiet power of unknown length.
For lying alone does not mean weak,
But rather, wisdom that she seeks.

She lies alone upon her bed,
Rebuilding worlds inside her head.

She lies alone upon her bed
While galaxies swirl overhead
Not on the ceiling, but behind
The universe within her mind

The sheets like dunes of desert sand
Shift with each movement of her hand
A traveler in lands unseen
A queen without a land to glean

The clock's tick-tocking fades away

Time has no meaning in this space
Where solitude and she embrace

Perhaps there's freedom in this state
No expectations, no debate
Just breathing in and breathing out

She lies alone upon her bed
Yet multitudes exist instead

She lies alone upon her bed,
A tapestry of thoughts unwed,
To action or to spoken word,

The ceiling maps her journey's route,
Through valleys deep of fear and doubt,
Across the mountains of desire,

Her fingers trace the empty sheets,
Where once two hearts in rhythm beat,

The night surrounds with star-flecked arms,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

responses.text:
She lies alone upon her bed,
A canvas of thoughts inside her head.
Moonlight streams through tattered blinds,
Illuminating memories she cannot leave behind.

The clock ticks on in rhythmic beat,
A symphony to her heartbeat's retreat.
Photographs on walls tell tales of yesteryear,
Of laughter shared and moments dear.

She traces patterns on the ceiling,

The world outside continues to spin,
As she remains trapped within.

Yet in solitude, she finds her strength,
A quiet power that grows at length.

She lies alone upon her bed,
Whispers of shadow dance overhead.
The weight of absence fills the room,
Heavy as thunder before the storm's bloom.

Fingers clutch sheets once warmed by two,
Now cold as the distance between me and you.
The pillow catches silent tears,
Collecting sorrows of vanished years.

Outside her window, city lights gleam,
A thousand stories, a million dreams.
Yet here in darkness she remains,
A solitary heart wrapped in chains.

The night stretches endless, a void without end,
As memories of love she cannot transcend.
She lies alone upon her bed,
Awake with ghosts that will not shed.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A universe contained in flesh and bone.
Constellations of freckles map her skin,
Each one a world yet to be known.

The ceiling fan whirs a gentle lullaby,
As her chest rises, falls, in tidal motion.
She is an island in cotton seas,
Bordered by dreams and deep emotion.

Her fingers dance across worn pages,
Of stories that carry her far away.
A traveler without moving an inch,
From twilight hours until break of day.

In solitude she finds expansion,
A freedom that partnership never gave.
She lies alone upon her bed,
Not abandoned, but gloriously saved.

She lies alone upon her bed,
The warrior rests her weary shield.
Battles fought in boardrooms harsh,

Her armor shed—soft cotton now,

She lies alone upon her bed,

She lies alone upon her bed,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Per me si va nella citta dolente.'

responses.text:
Through me the way to the city of sorrow,
Where ancient tears carve rivers through stone,
And whispers of the damned await tomorrow,
In chambers where no light has ever shone.

Per me si va nella città dolente,
Dante's warning echoes through time's veil,
A threshold crossed becomes one's sole repentant,
When hope abandoned sets the final sail.

I walked that path with shadows at my heels,
The gates of anguish opened wide and deep,
Revealing truths that mortal heart conceals,
And secrets that the living cannot keep.

Yet in this darkness, strange illumination—
A beauty in the suffering we bear,
The recognition of our shared damnation,
Unites us in the comfort of despair.

For cities built of sorrow still contain
The essence of humanity, complete.
Through me, the way to wisdom born of pain,
Where bitter knowledge makes surrender sweet.

THROUGH THE GATES

Per me si va nella città dolente,
Through me one enters the grieving city,
Where cobblestones remember ancient feet
And buildings lean to whisper secrets.

I stand before these iron gates,
Trembling like Dante at hell's dark threshold,
Feeling the weight of what's been lost—
A paradise of innocence abandoned.

Each step forward echoes with regret,
The city's sorrow seeps through cracked walls,
Painting shadows across my face
As I become what I've always feared.

Yet something pulls me deeper still,
Past boarded windows and broken dreams,
A strange attraction to this wounded place
Where truth no longer wears disguise.

Perhaps in cities built of grief
We find ourselves most honestly reflected,
Stripped of pretense, laid bare and real—
The dolente in our souls finally confessed.

LAMENTATIONS OF PASSAGE

Per me si va nella città dolente—
Through me, the pathway to the grieving city.
I am the doorway to forgotten realms,
Where shadows dance in perpetual twilight.

The ancient words carved upon the archway
Speak not just of Dante's infernal journey,
But of every human heart that breaks,
Every soul that wanders lost and searching.

I have walked these streets of lamentation,
Felt the cobblestones, slick with tears beneath my feet.
The buildings lean inward, whispering secrets
That only the truly broken can understand.

In this città dolente, this city of sorrow,
The currency is memory, the language is regret.
Yet strange flowers bloom in cracks of despair—
Beauty emerging from what we cannot forget.

So enter if you must, as all eventually do,
For the passage through suffering shapes us all.
The city dolente waits with open arms,
And in its embrace, we finally stand tall.

DESCENT

Per me si va nella città dolente—
Through me lies the path to sorrow's domain.
I stand at the threshold, trembling,
As ancient words echo through my veins.

The poet knew this journey well,
This descent into the spiraling dark,
Where conscience meets its reckoning
And souls bear their eternal mark.

Is it courage or folly that drives us?
To walk willingly into grief's embrace,
To trace the footsteps of the damned
And seek wisdom in that haunted place?

The city mourns with voices countless,
A chorus of regret that never ends.
Yet something beautiful resides there—
The truth that breaks before it mends.

So I enter, as all must someday enter,
The gates that separate light from shade.
For in the city of lamentation,
The foundations of wisdom are laid.

INFERNAL PASSAGES

Per me si va nella città dolente,
The words inscribed above the shadowed gate.
I trace them with my fingertips, hesitant,
Knowing some thresholds, once crossed, seal fate.

The grieving city calls with siren voice,
Its streets paved with intentions unfulfilled,
Its towers built from broken promises,
Its rivers flowing with tears we've spilled.

Dante knew this journey was necessary—
To walk through darkness to find the light,
To witness suffering to value joy,
To embrace the wrong to know the right.

So I step forward into that dolente realm,
Where lamentations echo off stone walls,
Where every shadow holds a memory,
And every memory still enthralls.

For cities built of sorrow teach us most
About the fragile nature of our souls.
Through me the way to wisdom hard-earned,
Through suffering, we finally become whole.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Born in the famine struck Africa'

responses.text:
DUST AND DREAMS

Born in the famine struck Africa,
Where the soil cracks like ancient parchment,
And the sky withholds its mercy.
My first cries merged with those of mothers
Whose breasts had nothing left to give.

The vultures circled overhead,
Patient witnesses to our struggle,
While aid workers with foreign tongues
Brought blue tarps and measured portions,
Their cameras capturing our hollow eyes.

Yet in this cradle of hunger,
I learned that hope grows like wild grass—
Stubbornly, between impossible stones.
My grandmother sang songs of rain
That would someday come to quench our land.

I carry Africa in my bones now,
A continent of contradictions:
Beauty and brutality, wealth and want.
From famine's edge, I emerged
Not just surviving, but seeing—
The world through eyes that know the cost
Of every drop, every grain, every breath.

HUNGER'S CHILD

Born in the famine struck Africa,
I entered a world of dust and waiting lines,
Where bellies spoke louder than voices
And the rain had forgotten its way home.

My mother's lullabies were prayers for grain,
Her embrace a fortress against the hollow days.
The elders said I arrived with the dry season—
Another mouth when mouths were burdens.

I learned to walk on soil that yielded nothing,
To recognize the sound of UN trucks before they appeared,
To measure life in ration cards and water drops,
To find joy in the shadow of a baobab tree.

They photographed our bones,
Turned our hunger into headlines,
Never seeing how we danced under stars,
How we wove stories from the threads of survival.

I am not just famine's child,
I am descendant of warriors and dreamers.
From cracked earth, I grow toward the sun,
A testimony that Africa is not just what it lacks,
But what it creates from emptiness.

INHERITANCE

Born in the famine struck Africa,
I inherited the resilience of acacia trees,
Their roots digging deep beyond the drought,
Their branches reaching skyward despite thirst.

My cradle was fashioned from necessity,
My swaddling clothes, whatever could be spared.
The news cameras captured my protruding ribs,
But missed the fire in my infant eyes.

My mother walked miles each day for water,
Returning with stories gathered like firewood—
Tales of ancestors who survived worse,
Who danced through hardship under ancient moons.

I grew alongside the foreign aid,
Learned English from relief workers,
Swahili from neighbors in the camp,
And dignity from elders who refused to be pitied.

Now I stand between worlds,
A bridge built from bones that didn't break.
The famine that welcomed me to Earth
Did not define my path but carved it—
A channel for compassion that flows
From the very place that once knew only thirst.

BIRTHRIGHT

Born in the famine struck Africa,
Where dust devils danced across barren fields
And children's eyes held universes of hunger.
I was baptized not in water—too precious—
But in the collective breath of waiting.

My first toys were empty food cans,
Shiny treasures from distant lands
Where people never knew the mathematics of survival:
Dividing one meal to feed many mouths,
Multiplying hope when resources subtract.

The foreign journalists called it catastrophe,
Their lenses capturing skeletal frames,
But missing how my village elders
Taught geometry by drawing in sand,
Passed down oral histories under thorn trees.

I learned early that hunger is a teacher—
It shows what matters, what endures.
While my belly twisted with want,
My mind expanded with the vastness of stars
That peppered our unobstructed sky.

From famine's cruel classroom I graduated
With a degree in persistence,
A doctorate in finding joy amid scarcity.
Africa was not just my birthplace of hardship,
But my school of immeasurable strength.

ROOTS IN PARCHED SOIL

Born in the famine struck Africa,
Where vultures circled like dark prophecies
And relief trucks raised dust clouds of hope.
I came into being when life seemed impossible—
A stubborn green shoot in cracked earth.

My first language was not words but whimpers,
The universal dialect of empty stomachs.
My mother's milk dried up with the rivers,
Yet somehow she found ways to nourish me
With determination thicker than blood.

The white tents of aid organizations
Became my childhood landmarks,
Foreign faces with clipboards and cameras
Counting us, documenting our suffering,
Rarely seeing our dignity beneath the dust.

I played games with shadows when toys were luxuries,
Learned patience watching clouds that brought no rain,
Found wealth in stories told around sparse fires.

Now when people ask where I'm from,
I tell them I sprouted from impossibility,
A child of drought who carries oceans within,
Proof that even the harshest beginnings
Can nurture souls of extraordinary depth.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Homer poured, in thousand wrote.'

responses.text:
Epic Ink

Homer poured, in thousand wrote,
Tales of heroes long ago.
Ink from ancient wells he smote
Upon parchment, ebb and flow.

Odysseus wandered, Hector fell,
Words cascading through the ages.
Timeless stories, cast their spell,
Echoing from sacred pages.

From one mind, a river flows,
Carving canyons through our souls.
Thousand verses, thousand woes,
Thousand triumphs, thousand goals.

Homer poured his vision vast,
Drops of wisdom, ocean deep.
Through millennia they've passed,
Secrets that the muses keep.

In his wake, we writers stand,
Humble vessels, waiting filled.
Ink-stained fingers, pen in hand,
Hoping time won't see us stilled.

The Ancient Scribe

Homer poured, in thousand wrote,
Blind eyes seeing beyond sight.
His words, like ships that gently float
Across time's sea through darkest night.

A thousand heroes, thousand tales,
Spun from the thread of memory's loom.
Of Troy's great walls and billowed sails,
Of glory earned and pending doom.

He poured his soul in meter sweet,
Each hexameter a vessel true.
Where mortal hearts and gods would meet
In realms both terrible and new.

The wine of wisdom filled each line,
Intoxicating minds through age.
His thoughts, like stars, eternal shine,
Illuminating history's page.

So when we drink from ancient streams,
Remember him who poured them forth.
Whose thousand verses, thousand dreams,
Still quench our thirst for timeless worth.

Immortal Vessels

Homer poured, in thousand wrote,
Ambrosia for the starving mind.
Each syllable a wooden boat,
Upon seas of thought designed.

He poured the wine of ancient days
Into cups of metered verse.
Through blind eyes saw the human ways,
Our blessings and our curse.

A thousand stories from his hand,
Of gods who walked on mortal soil.
Of heroes' deeds in foreign land,
Of love and hate and mortal toil.

The Trojan walls still standing tall
Within the architecture of his words.
Achilles' rage, Hector's fall,
Still echo like the songs of birds.

So when we write our humble lines,
Remember him who came before.
Whose epic pour through sands of time
Still nourishes our literary shore.

The Poet's Fountain

Homer poured, in thousand wrote,
From wellsprings deep within his soul.
Each word a shimmering, sacred note
That made the broken cosmos whole.

Blind eyes that saw beyond the veil
Of mortal sight and human ken.
He wove his epic, thread by tail,
With nothing but his voice and pen.

A thousand heroes, thousand deeds,
Poured forth like honey from the comb.
A thousand hearts, a thousand needs,
All seeking glory, seeking home.

The wine of ages filled his cup,
And from that vessel, legends grew.
From humble clay, he lifted up
A mirror where we see the true.

So when we thirst for beauty's face,
We drink from Homer's endless stream.
And in his flowing, find the grace
To pour our own thousand-fold dream.

The Eternal Flow

Homer poured, in thousand wrote,
Visions from the Muses' spring.
Like wine from an eternal throat,
Words that made the heavens sing.

Blind eyes peering through the veil
Of time and space and mortal fear.
He crafted every hero's tale
With voice that gods themselves would hear.

His amphora of epic verse
Decanted through three thousand years.
The sweetest joy, the darkest curse,
Humanity's own hopes and fears.

A thousand lines from one man's soul,
A thousand stories intertwined.
The fragments forming one great whole,
The map of all mankind.

So when we sip from modern streams,
Remember who first tilled this earth.
For Homer's pour still flows and teems
In every poem given birth.
